• Templates
An AI-powered knowledge hub can save hours for your team every single day. Learn how to build, roll out, and maintain your AI-powered knowledge hub in Notion.
• Set your hub strategy and get stakeholder alignment

Chunk 561:
• Start with a teamspace, fill it with templates
• Selecting use-case specific trackers
• Move, import, and create your content
• Polish and publish
• Share your hub with your team
• Announce your hub, train your team
• Grow & maintain your hub
• Tips & tricks for growing your hub over time
 Employees often struggle to find the information they need, leading to inefficiencies in your work and theirs — and costing your business in big ways.

Chunk 562:
We dreamed up with our customers of a better way to create and find your knowledge, and it's called an AI knowledge hub. These hubs can help you empower employees to find and understand information they need to do their jobs.
 Whether you’re onboarding new employees, creating single source of truth for your engineering documentation, supporting a customer experience team at scale, or looking for a low-lift way to deflect internal IT tickets, a knowledge hub with AI Q&A will help you do it.
 In this guide, we’ll cover everything you need to know to build, roll out, and maintain your knowledge hub.
Set your hub strategy and get stakeholder alignment

Chunk 563:
While you might be eager to dive into your knowledge hub build-out (as are we), it’s important to start with a plan. A successful AI implementation includes a clear strategic goal, identifying who will use your knowledge hub, what information they will find, and why you’re investing in building one at all.
 Consider the following tasks before you embark on building your knowledge hub in Notion:
• Identify who will use your hub — Determine the primary users of your knowledge hub. This could include employees, departments, or specific teams that will rely on the hub for information.

Chunk 564:
• Determine key stakeholders — Identify the people who will have a significant influence on the development and success of your knowledge hub. This is likely a group of folks including a Notion champion, a knowledge manager, an IT admin, and other folks that make sense within the context of your org (like bizops, or a chief of staff where relevant).
• Assess current state and gather user feedback — Collect input from potential users to understand their needs and expectations for the knowledge hub. Learn where your audience is finding (or not finding) answers to their questions, and determine how long it’s currently taking them to do so. Your goal throughout this project will be to reduce that time spent searching.

Chunk 565:
• Find your documentation and create a content map for future state — Next, dive into your docs. What questions can be answered with current documentation? Do you need to write new docs? Update old ones? Write this all down, you’ll come back to it later on.
• Set a measurable ROI goal — At this point, we hope you have a sense of the pain points in your current workflows. That means it’s time to set a tangible goal for your upcoming project! Notion AI can help teams save significant time from searching for information and increase their overall productivity and satisfaction at work. Use the Notion AI ROI calculator to set a goal for your team.

Chunk 566:
Identify who will use your hub — Determine the primary users of your knowledge hub. This could include employees, departments, or specific teams that will rely on the hub for information.
 Determine key stakeholders — Identify the people who will have a significant influence on the development and success of your knowledge hub. This is likely a group of folks including a Notion champion, a knowledge manager, an IT admin, and other folks that make sense within the context of your org (like bizops, or a chief of staff where relevant).

Chunk 567:
Assess current state and gather user feedback — Collect input from potential users to understand their needs and expectations for the knowledge hub. Learn where your audience is finding (or not finding) answers to their questions, and determine how long it’s currently taking them to do so. Your goal throughout this project will be to reduce that time spent searching.
 Find your documentation and create a content map for future state — Next, dive into your docs. What questions can be answered with current documentation? Do you need to write new docs? Update old ones? Write this all down, you’ll come back to it later on.

Chunk 568:
Set a measurable ROI goal — At this point, we hope you have a sense of the pain points in your current workflows. That means it’s time to set a tangible goal for your upcoming project! Notion AI can help teams save significant time from searching for information and increase their overall productivity and satisfaction at work. Use the Notion AI ROI calculator to set a goal for your team.
 The rest of this guide will walk you through the steps your team needs to take to transition from your current state to your new knowledge hub in Notion. Happy building!
 We’re here to help!
 Reach out to our sales team for support to start building your strategy with an experienced partner.
Create a space for your hub

Chunk 569:
Your team does its best work when everyone on it has access to the information they need to do their jobs, when they need it. Just like the entrance to your physical office sets the stage for a productive working day, your knowledge hub home-base sets (appropriately) high expectations for what your users will find in Notion.
Start with a teamspace, fill it with templates

Chunk 570:
Begin by setting up a dedicated teamspace for your knowledge hub. This space will serve as the central location where all knowledge hub templates and resources are stored. Make sure it is easily accessible to all team members who will be contributing to or using the hub, either by making it a “default” teamspace (so members are added automatically), or by setting the permissions to open such that anyone can join.
 Once your teamspace is setup, you can begin building the architecture for your hub. For now, focus just on how users will navigate the hub. At a minimum, your knowledge hub template will include the following components.
 Skip this step with templates for every team
 We created best-in-class templates for your knowledge:

Chunk 571:
• Onboarding hub
• Customer support hub
• IT trouble shooting hub, or
• Legal and compliance hub
 Engineering hub
 Onboarding hub
 Customer support hub
 IT trouble shooting hub, or
 Legal and compliance hub
 To use these templates, duplicate them into your workspace, and move each page into the sidebar of your newly created teamspace. Then, read on for guidance on filling your hub with content and rolling it out to your team.

Chunk 572:
• Top level page — you’ll want to utilize a single, top-level page to act as a landing place for your knowledge hub. This is a place for your team to get a birds-eye-view of the information in your hub, and an understanding of how they can use it. It’s also a great place to mention pages that you want to draw attention to, or request feedback (more on that later).

Chunk 573:
• Wiki database (part of your top level page) — once your top-level page is established, you can use the “Turn to Wiki” button in the ... menu on the top left of your Notion page to create a new view for organizing sub-pages. Adding pages into a database will help immensely as you organize and scale your knowledge hub thanks to properties like tags and verification. Learn more about wiki databases here →

Chunk 574:
Top level page — you’ll want to utilize a single, top-level page to act as a landing place for your knowledge hub. This is a place for your team to get a birds-eye-view of the information in your hub, and an understanding of how they can use it. It’s also a great place to mention pages that you want to draw attention to, or request feedback (more on that later).

Chunk 575:
Wiki database (part of your top level page) — once your top-level page is established, you can use the “Turn to Wiki” button in the ... menu on the top left of your Notion page to create a new view for organizing sub-pages. Adding pages into a database will help immensely as you organize and scale your knowledge hub thanks to properties like tags and verification. Learn more about wiki databases here →
• FAQs — the FAQ database serves two important purposes as you build out your knowledge hub. First, it creates a repository for key bits of information that are otherwise buried in long documents. Second, it helps AI more easily find the answers to commonly asked questions, ensuring your team gets what they need as quickly as possible.

Chunk 576:
• AI Q&A — make sure you see the AI icon in the bottom right hand corner of your app (if not, check to make sure you have AI enabled in “settings”). This is where you and your end users will go to ask questions about the content in the knowledge hub.
 FAQs — the FAQ database serves two important purposes as you build out your knowledge hub. First, it creates a repository for key bits of information that are otherwise buried in long documents. Second, it helps AI more easily find the answers to commonly asked questions, ensuring your team gets what they need as quickly as possible.

Chunk 577:
AI Q&A — make sure you see the AI icon in the bottom right hand corner of your app (if not, check to make sure you have AI enabled in “settings”). This is where you and your end users will go to ask questions about the content in the knowledge hub.
• Use-case specific trackers — These are tailored to meet the specific needs of different teams within your organization — like a product feedback tracker, or IT request system. They help in gaining insight into workflows, tracking progress, and ensuring that everyone has access to the necessary information.

Chunk 578:
Use-case specific trackers — These are tailored to meet the specific needs of different teams within your organization — like a product feedback tracker, or IT request system. They help in gaining insight into workflows, tracking progress, and ensuring that everyone has access to the necessary information.
 New to building in Notion?
 Click to expand
Selecting use-case specific trackers

Chunk 579:
Knowledge management in a modern workspace goes beyond just the documentation inside your wiki. Your employees need to find answers to more dynamic questions too — like the status of their IT ticket, whether someone else has recently left feedback on a specific product area, and so much more. A knowledge base that doubles as a tracker for your day-to-day work makes this dream a reality.
 Consider the following examples. Each of these leverage Notion’s flexible structure to organize information in a way that is both accessible and actionable, enabling teams to collaborate more effectively.
 Trackers for your team
 Click to expand

Chunk 580:
Before moving on, decide what additional information you want to add to your hub and build out the initial framework (or better yet, use one of our templates above).
 Want to go deeper on building your workspace architecture?
 Click to expand
Fill your hub with content
 Once you’ve set up the architecture of your knowledge hub, you’re ready to start adding your team’s content. This will likely be the longest step in your process, but will pay dividends when it’s time to roll your hub out to your end users. Remember that a knowledge hub is only as valuable as the quality of knowledge housed within it.
Move, import, and create your content

Chunk 581:
Remember how we told you to write down the docs you want to have in your knowledge hub? Time to grab that content map once again (or finish it if you haven’t yet). Once you have a high-level understanding of all the documents and FAQs that you want to add to your hub, you’ll start the heavy lifting. There are three main ways to bring content into your hub:
• Import content from other apps — Bring in existing content from tools like Google Docs, Confluence, Asana, or even PDFs. Centralize your team’s information and make it easily accessible within Notion by placing these pages into your Wiki.

Chunk 582:
Import content from other apps — Bring in existing content from tools like Google Docs, Confluence, Asana, or even PDFs. Centralize your team’s information and make it easily accessible within Notion by placing these pages into your Wiki.
• Use Move to to gather content from your Notion workspace — Consolidate all relevant Notion pages into your knowledge hub by using the Move to function and moving them into your new wiki database. This helps to keep your workspace organized and ensure that all necessary information is in one place.

Chunk 583:
• Create new content, and use AI to help — AI can help you start from scratch to create a draft in seconds so all you have to do is add the extra information your team needs. Like uploaded files, video recordings, or even slide decks. Plus, If you’re working through half-baked docs, or translating very technical language, try using Notion AI to expand and organize your thoughts into comprehensive, well-structured content.
 Use Move to to gather content from your Notion workspace — Consolidate all relevant Notion pages into your knowledge hub by using the Move to function and moving them into your new wiki database. This helps to keep your workspace organized and ensure that all necessary information is in one place.

Chunk 584:
Create new content, and use AI to help — AI can help you start from scratch to create a draft in seconds so all you have to do is add the extra information your team needs. Like uploaded files, video recordings, or even slide decks. Plus, If you’re working through half-baked docs, or translating very technical language, try using Notion AI to expand and organize your thoughts into comprehensive, well-structured content.
 Integrate with other tools
 Click to expand
Add AI connectors
 AI connectors extend the reach of your self-serve knowledge hub, allowing your end-users to access the most up-to-date answers to their questions, even if they haven’t been documented (yet). Learn more about AI connectors here.
Polish and publish

Chunk 585:
You’re almost ready to share your knowledge hub with the world! Before you do, dot your metaphorical “i”s and cross your metaphorical “t”s by making sure your information is well categorized and organized. Here are a few things we recommend:
• Clean up your page icons — you’d be surprised how far a couple of intentionally picked page icons can go when it comes to rolling out a nicely packaged knowledge hub. When in doubt, pick a color palette and give every page an icon of that color.
• Add a welcoming callout — on your top-level page, add a quick callout explaining what users are looking at, and how they’ll interact with it, and who to contact with questions. This helps to reduce the mental overhead required to engage with a new tool.

Chunk 586:
Clean up your page icons — you’d be surprised how far a couple of intentionally picked page icons can go when it comes to rolling out a nicely packaged knowledge hub. When in doubt, pick a color palette and give every page an icon of that color.
 Add a welcoming callout — on your top-level page, add a quick callout explaining what users are looking at, and how they’ll interact with it, and who to contact with questions. This helps to reduce the mental overhead required to engage with a new tool.
• Tag pages in your wiki — Use relevant tags to categorize your pages. This helps in searching and filtering information quickly.

Chunk 587:
Tag pages in your wiki — Use relevant tags to categorize your pages. This helps in searching and filtering information quickly.
Share your hub with your team
 It’s the moment you’ve been waiting for! Rolling out your knowledge hub to your team is a huge accomplishment, but it isn’t the end of the road. In order to ensure your end users get value out of your knowledge hub, you’ll need to invest time into training them on how to use it, and continuously reinforce it’s existence.
Configure permissions for your hub

Chunk 588:
Before you jump into training your team, make sure the right people have the right access to maintain and update your knowledge hub effectively. You’ll manage permissions in the teamspace settings menu, and should deal with users in two primary groups:
• Add teamspace owners — Teamspace owners act as the primary knowledge curators. They are responsible for the overall organization, structure, and maintenance of the knowledge hub. You’ll want to give them Full Access so that they can create, edit, and delete all pages within the teamspace. As teamspace owners, they’ll also be able to adjust teamspace settings, invite/remove members, and manage permissions.

Chunk 589:
• Then, add teamspace Members — Teamspace members contribute to the knowledge base by adding new information, updating existing content, and actively engaging with the AI-powered features. They are also the primary consumers of the knowledge. Give them “Can edit” permissions to edit existing pages and create new pages within the teamspace.

Chunk 590:
Add teamspace owners — Teamspace owners act as the primary knowledge curators. They are responsible for the overall organization, structure, and maintenance of the knowledge hub. You’ll want to give them Full Access so that they can create, edit, and delete all pages within the teamspace. As teamspace owners, they’ll also be able to adjust teamspace settings, invite/remove members, and manage permissions.
 Then, add teamspace Members — Teamspace members contribute to the knowledge base by adding new information, updating existing content, and actively engaging with the AI-powered features. They are also the primary consumers of the knowledge. Give them “Can edit” permissions to edit existing pages and create new pages within the teamspace.

Chunk 591:
Teamspaces are Notion’s solution to complex permission requirements
 Click to expand
Announce your hub, train your team
 Now that everyone has access to your knowledge hub, it’s time to announce your hub and train your team. You’ll know what announcement channels tend to work best for your company (and we have some tips below, too!), but dont forget to teach your audience how to use your new tool.
 To start, make sure your end users have the resources they need to navigate your knowledge hub. In your announcement comms, focus on helping users learn how to navigate using the sidebar, and how to get answers about work content faster with Q&A.

Chunk 592:
Start emphasizing the value of Notion AI, even demo-ing some questions that users can find the answers to within your new and improved knowledge hub.
 Give your team the resources they need
 Click to expand
Focus on internal communications
 If a resource is created, and no one knows about it, does it even exist? Internal comms are a vital component of your rollout strategy, and you should expect to spend a few weeks (up to a few months) showing off your new hub. Here’s just a few ideas that have helped our customers:

Chunk 593:
• Start with a pilot group — for a bigger roll out, consider starting with a pilot. A diverse pilot group across departments can help test the knowledge hub and gather feedback on usability, content, and AI effectiveness before a larger launch.
• Preview your hub in a team meeting or all hands — schedule a dedicated session to walk through the knowledge hub, highlight key features, and demonstrate how to use it effectively. This ensures everyone is familiar with the new resource.
• Send written communications about your hub — draft an email or internal memo that outlines the purpose of the knowledge hub, provides usage instructions, and includes a link to access it. This helps to reinforce the hub's importance and utility.

Chunk 594:
• Stop answering questions — this is the hardest, and most important component of a successful knowledge hub rollout. In order to build new habits, you’ll want to continuously re-direct your question-asking colleagues to your new and improved knowledge hub. Gently remind them to ask their question to Notion AI before asking in your slack channel or DMs.
 Start with a pilot group — for a bigger roll out, consider starting with a pilot. A diverse pilot group across departments can help test the knowledge hub and gather feedback on usability, content, and AI effectiveness before a larger launch.

Chunk 595:
Preview your hub in a team meeting or all hands — schedule a dedicated session to walk through the knowledge hub, highlight key features, and demonstrate how to use it effectively. This ensures everyone is familiar with the new resource.
 Send written communications about your hub — draft an email or internal memo that outlines the purpose of the knowledge hub, provides usage instructions, and includes a link to access it. This helps to reinforce the hub's importance and utility.

Chunk 596:
Stop answering questions — this is the hardest, and most important component of a successful knowledge hub rollout. In order to build new habits, you’ll want to continuously re-direct your question-asking colleagues to your new and improved knowledge hub. Gently remind them to ask their question to Notion AI before asking in your slack channel or DMs.
Grow & maintain your hub
 Think of your wiki as a garden. Just as a garden needs regular tending to flourish, your knowledge hub requires continuous updates and care. Plant new ideas, prune outdated information, and nurture the content to keep it vibrant and useful for everyone who visits.
Keep your content fresh

Chunk 597:
One of the worst detractors to the long-term health of your knowledge hub is stale or outdated content. That’s why it’s important to set up systems to keep your content fresh.
 We recommend starting with the following:
• Add verified properties — verified properties ensure that the information in your knowledge hub is accurate and trustworthy. Implement a process where subject matter experts review and approve content on a regular cadence. They’ll get notifications when their content is about to expire.
• Create an “admin” view — an admin view allows administrators to oversee and manage the content more efficiently. This view can include filters and sorting options to quickly identify outdated or inaccurate information.

Chunk 598:
Add verified properties — verified properties ensure that the information in your knowledge hub is accurate and trustworthy. Implement a process where subject matter experts review and approve content on a regular cadence. They’ll get notifications when their content is about to expire.
 Create an “admin” view — an admin view allows administrators to oversee and manage the content more efficiently. This view can include filters and sorting options to quickly identify outdated or inaccurate information.

Chunk 599:
• Keep content in a single database — Centralizing your content in one database prevents information sprawl and makes it easier to maintain. This structure helps in keeping the knowledge hub organized and ensures that users can find information quickly. Learn more about how Notion AI finds answers here.
• Utilize AI autofill — AI can summarize or extract information from all of your wiki entries at once based on a single prompt. This can help to save time by generating answers based on text in a page, without you having to read through each one manually.

Chunk 600:
Keep content in a single database — Centralizing your content in one database prevents information sprawl and makes it easier to maintain. This structure helps in keeping the knowledge hub organized and ensures that users can find information quickly. Learn more about how Notion AI finds answers here.
 Utilize AI autofill — AI can summarize or extract information from all of your wiki entries at once based on a single prompt. This can help to save time by generating answers based on text in a page, without you having to read through each one manually.
Tips & tricks for growing your hub over time

Chunk 601:
• Add an upvote button — Encourage users to interact with content by giving it an upvote. This helps prioritize valuable information. Learn more about database buttons here.
• Create a feedback database — Set up a database to collect and manage user feedback about the knowledge hub itself to assist with continuous improvement.
 Add an upvote button — Encourage users to interact with content by giving it an upvote. This helps prioritize valuable information. Learn more about database buttons here.
 Create a feedback database — Set up a database to collect and manage user feedback about the knowledge hub itself to assist with continuous improvement.

Chunk 602:
• Use page analytics — these can help you see which what content is getting the most use and prioritize updates accordingly.
• Schedule regular content reviews — set up a recurring schedule to review and update the information in your knowledge hub. This ensures that the content remains relevant and accurate over time.
 Use page analytics — these can help you see which what content is getting the most use and prioritize updates accordingly.
 Schedule regular content reviews — set up a recurring schedule to review and update the information in your knowledge hub. This ensures that the content remains relevant and accurate over time.

Chunk 603:
Building and maintaining an AI-powered knowledge hub in Notion is an ongoing process that requires careful planning, organization, and continuous improvement. By following the steps outlined in this guide, you can create a valuable resource that not only helps your team access the information they need but also leverages the power of AI to keep your documentation up-to-date and easily searchable. Remember, the key to a successful knowledge hub is engagement and feedback from your users, so make sure to encourage interaction and continuously refine your content based on their needs.
 Additional resources as you build your knowledge hub
• Get to know Notion AI better with our collection of AI-related guides.

Chunk 604:
• If you’re an IT admin who is new to Notion, the ultimate quickstart guide to Notion for Enterprise might be a good primer on all things people, sharing, and security.
• For builders, Notion Academy is a one-stop shop for learning everything you need to know. Find courses about scaling your team, managing an enterprise workspace, and more.
• Finally, understanding how Q&A finds answers can help you get better results — read the specifics in this guide.

An AI-powered knowledge hub can save hours for your team every single day. Learn how to build, roll out, and maintain your AI-powered knowledge hub in Notion.
• Set your hub strategy and get stakeholder alignment

Chunk 609:
• Start with a teamspace, fill it with templates
• Selecting use-case specific trackers
• Move, import, and create your content
• Polish and publish
• Share your hub with your team
• Announce your hub, train your team
• Grow & maintain your hub
• Tips & tricks for growing your hub over time
 Employees often struggle to find the information they need, leading to inefficiencies in your work and theirs — and costing your business in big ways.

Chunk 610:
We dreamed up with our customers of a better way to create and find your knowledge, and it's called an AI knowledge hub. These hubs can help you empower employees to find and understand information they need to do their jobs.
 Whether you’re onboarding new employees, creating single source of truth for your engineering documentation, supporting a customer experience team at scale, or looking for a low-lift way to deflect internal IT tickets, a knowledge hub with AI Q&A will help you do it.
 In this guide, we’ll cover everything you need to know to build, roll out, and maintain your knowledge hub.
Set your hub strategy and get stakeholder alignment

Chunk 611:
While you might be eager to dive into your knowledge hub build-out (as are we), it’s important to start with a plan. A successful AI implementation includes a clear strategic goal, identifying who will use your knowledge hub, what information they will find, and why you’re investing in building one at all.
 Consider the following tasks before you embark on building your knowledge hub in Notion:
• Identify who will use your hub — Determine the primary users of your knowledge hub. This could include employees, departments, or specific teams that will rely on the hub for information.

Chunk 612:
• Determine key stakeholders — Identify the people who will have a significant influence on the development and success of your knowledge hub. This is likely a group of folks including a Notion champion, a knowledge manager, an IT admin, and other folks that make sense within the context of your org (like bizops, or a chief of staff where relevant).
• Assess current state and gather user feedback — Collect input from potential users to understand their needs and expectations for the knowledge hub. Learn where your audience is finding (or not finding) answers to their questions, and determine how long it’s currently taking them to do so. Your goal throughout this project will be to reduce that time spent searching.

Chunk 613:
• Find your documentation and create a content map for future state — Next, dive into your docs. What questions can be answered with current documentation? Do you need to write new docs? Update old ones? Write this all down, you’ll come back to it later on.
• Set a measurable ROI goal — At this point, we hope you have a sense of the pain points in your current workflows. That means it’s time to set a tangible goal for your upcoming project! Notion AI can help teams save significant time from searching for information and increase their overall productivity and satisfaction at work. Use the Notion AI ROI calculator to set a goal for your team.

Chunk 614:
Identify who will use your hub — Determine the primary users of your knowledge hub. This could include employees, departments, or specific teams that will rely on the hub for information.
 Determine key stakeholders — Identify the people who will have a significant influence on the development and success of your knowledge hub. This is likely a group of folks including a Notion champion, a knowledge manager, an IT admin, and other folks that make sense within the context of your org (like bizops, or a chief of staff where relevant).

Chunk 615:
Assess current state and gather user feedback — Collect input from potential users to understand their needs and expectations for the knowledge hub. Your goal throughout this project will be to reduce that time spent searching.

They help in gaining insight into workflows, tracking progress, and ensuring that everyone has access to the necessary information.

Chunk 626:
Use-case specific trackers — These are tailored to meet the specific needs of different teams within your organization — like a product feedback tracker, or IT request system. They help in gaining insight into workflows, tracking progress, and ensuring that everyone has access to the necessary information.
 New to building in Notion?
 Click to expand
Selecting use-case specific trackers

Chunk 627:
Knowledge management in a modern workspace goes beyond just the documentation inside your wiki. Your employees need to find answers to more dynamic questions too — like the status of their IT ticket, whether someone else has recently left feedback on a specific product area, and so much more. A knowledge base that doubles as a tracker for your day-to-day work makes this dream a reality.
 Consider the following examples. Each of these leverage Notion’s flexible structure to organize information in a way that is both accessible and actionable, enabling teams to collaborate more effectively.
 Trackers for your team
 Click to expand

Chunk 628:
Before moving on, decide what additional information you want to add to your hub and build out the initial framework (or better yet, use one of our templates above).
 Want to go deeper on building your workspace architecture?
 Click to expand
Fill your hub with content
 Once you’ve set up the architecture of your knowledge hub, you’re ready to start adding your team’s content. This will likely be the longest step in your process, but will pay dividends when it’s time to roll your hub out to your end users. Remember that a knowledge hub is only as valuable as the quality of knowledge housed within it.
Move, import, and create your content

Chunk 629:
Remember how we told you to write down the docs you want to have in your knowledge hub? Time to grab that content map once again (or finish it if you haven’t yet). Once you have a high-level understanding of all the documents and FAQs that you want to add to your hub, you’ll start the heavy lifting. There are three main ways to bring content into your hub:
• Import content from other apps — Bring in existing content from tools like Google Docs, Confluence, Asana, or even PDFs. Centralize your team’s information and make it easily accessible within Notion by placing these pages into your Wiki.

Chunk 630:
Import content from other apps — Bring in existing content from tools like Google Docs, Confluence, Asana, or even PDFs. Centralize your team’s information and make it easily accessible within Notion by placing these pages into your Wiki.
• Use Move to to gather content from your Notion workspace — Consolidate all relevant Notion pages into your knowledge hub by using the Move to function and moving them into your new wiki database. This helps to keep your workspace organized and ensure that all necessary information is in one place.

Chunk 631:
• Create new content, and use AI to help — AI can help you start from scratch to create a draft in seconds so all you have to do is add the extra information your team needs. Like uploaded files, video recordings, or even slide decks. Plus, If you’re working through half-baked docs, or translating very technical language, try using Notion AI to expand and organize your thoughts into comprehensive, well-structured content.
 Use Move to to gather content from your Notion workspace — Consolidate all relevant Notion pages into your knowledge hub by using the Move to function and moving them into your new wiki database. This helps to keep your workspace organized and ensure that all necessary information is in one place.

Chunk 632:
Create new content, and use AI to help — AI can help you start from scratch to create a draft in seconds so all you have to do is add the extra information your team needs. Like uploaded files, video recordings, or even slide decks. Plus, If you’re working through half-baked docs, or translating very technical language, try using Notion AI to expand and organize your thoughts into comprehensive, well-structured content.
 Integrate with other tools
 Click to expand
Add AI connectors
 AI connectors extend the reach of your self-serve knowledge hub, allowing your end-users to access the most up-to-date answers to their questions, even if they haven’t been documented (yet). Learn more about AI connectors here.
Polish and publish

Chunk 633:
You’re almost ready to share your knowledge hub with the world! Before you do, dot your metaphorical “i”s and cross your metaphorical “t”s by making sure your information is well categorized and organized. Here are a few things we recommend:
• Clean up your page icons — you’d be surprised how far a couple of intentionally picked page icons can go when it comes to rolling out a nicely packaged knowledge hub. When in doubt, pick a color palette and give every page an icon of that color.
• Add a welcoming callout — on your top-level page, add a quick callout explaining what users are looking at, and how they’ll interact with it, and who to contact with questions. This helps to reduce the mental overhead required to engage with a new tool.

Chunk 634:
Clean up your page icons — you’d be surprised how far a couple of intentionally picked page icons can go when it comes to rolling out a nicely packaged knowledge hub. When in doubt, pick a color palette and give every page an icon of that color.
 Add a welcoming callout — on your top-level page, add a quick callout explaining what users are looking at, and how they’ll interact with it, and who to contact with questions. This helps to reduce the mental overhead required to engage with a new tool.
• Tag pages in your wiki — Use relevant tags to categorize your pages. This helps in searching and filtering information quickly.

Chunk 635:
Tag pages in your wiki — Use relevant tags to categorize your pages. This helps in searching and filtering information quickly.
Share your hub with your team
 It’s the moment you’ve been waiting for! Rolling out your knowledge hub to your team is a huge accomplishment, but it isn’t the end of the road. In order to ensure your end users get value out of your knowledge hub, you’ll need to invest time into training them on how to use it, and continuously reinforce it’s existence.
Configure permissions for your hub

Chunk 636:
Before you jump into training your team, make sure the right people have the right access to maintain and update your knowledge hub effectively. You’ll manage permissions in the teamspace settings menu, and should deal with users in two primary groups:
• Add teamspace owners — Teamspace owners act as the primary knowledge curators. They are responsible for the overall organization, structure, and maintenance of the knowledge hub. You’ll want to give them Full Access so that they can create, edit, and delete all pages within the teamspace. As teamspace owners, they’ll also be able to adjust teamspace settings, invite/remove members, and manage permissions.

Chunk 637:
• Then, add teamspace Members — Teamspace members contribute to the knowledge base by adding new information, updating existing content, and actively engaging with the AI-powered features. They are also the primary consumers of the knowledge. Give them “Can edit” permissions to edit existing pages and create new pages within the teamspace.

Chunk 638:
Add teamspace owners — Teamspace owners act as the primary knowledge curators. They are responsible for the overall organization, structure, and maintenance of the knowledge hub. You’ll want to give them Full Access so that they can create, edit, and delete all pages within the teamspace. As teamspace owners, they’ll also be able to adjust teamspace settings, invite/remove members, and manage permissions.
 Then, add teamspace Members — Teamspace members contribute to the knowledge base by adding new information, updating existing content, and actively engaging with the AI-powered features. They are also the primary consumers of the knowledge. Give them “Can edit” permissions to edit existing pages and create new pages within the teamspace.

Chunk 639:
Teamspaces are Notion’s solution to complex permission requirements
 Click to expand
Announce your hub, train your team
 Now that everyone has access to your knowledge hub, it’s time to announce your hub and train your team. You’ll know what announcement channels tend to work best for your company (and we have some tips below, too!), but dont forget to teach your audience how to use your new tool.
 To start, make sure your end users have the resources they need to navigate your knowledge hub. In your announcement comms, focus on helping users learn how to navigate using the sidebar, and how to get answers about work content faster with Q&A.

Chunk 640:
Start emphasizing the value of Notion AI, even demo-ing some questions that users can find the answers to within your new and improved knowledge hub.
 Give your team the resources they need
 Click to expand
Focus on internal communications
 If a resource is created, and no one knows about it, does it even exist? Internal comms are a vital component of your rollout strategy, and you should expect to spend a few weeks (up to a few months) showing off your new hub. Here’s just a few ideas that have helped our customers:

Chunk 641:
• Start with a pilot group — for a bigger roll out, consider starting with a pilot. A diverse pilot group across departments can help test the knowledge hub and gather feedback on usability, content, and AI effectiveness before a larger launch.
• Preview your hub in a team meeting or all hands — schedule a dedicated session to walk through the knowledge hub, highlight key features, and demonstrate how to use it effectively. This ensures everyone is familiar with the new resource.
• Send written communications about your hub — draft an email or internal memo that outlines the purpose of the knowledge hub, provides usage instructions, and includes a link to access it. This helps to reinforce the hub's importance and utility.

Chunk 642:
• Stop answering questions — this is the hardest, and most important component of a successful knowledge hub rollout. In order to build new habits, you’ll want to continuously re-direct your question-asking colleagues to your new and improved knowledge hub. Gently remind them to ask their question to Notion AI before asking in your slack channel or DMs.
 Start with a pilot group — for a bigger roll out, consider starting with a pilot. A diverse pilot group across departments can help test the knowledge hub and gather feedback on usability, content, and AI effectiveness before a larger launch.

Chunk 643:
Preview your hub in a team meeting or all hands — schedule a dedicated session to walk through the knowledge hub, highlight key features, and demonstrate how to use it effectively. This ensures everyone is familiar with the new resource.
 Send written communications about your hub — draft an email or internal memo that outlines the purpose of the knowledge hub, provides usage instructions, and includes a link to access it. This helps to reinforce the hub's importance and utility.

Chunk 644:
Stop answering questions — this is the hardest, and most important component of a successful knowledge hub rollout. In order to build new habits, you’ll want to continuously re-direct your question-asking colleagues to your new and improved knowledge hub. Gently remind them to ask their question to Notion AI before asking in your slack channel or DMs.
Grow & maintain your hub
 Think of your wiki as a garden. Just as a garden needs regular tending to flourish, your knowledge hub requires continuous updates and care. Plant new ideas, prune outdated information, and nurture the content to keep it vibrant and useful for everyone who visits.
Keep your content fresh

Chunk 645:
One of the worst detractors to the long-term health of your knowledge hub is stale or outdated content. That’s why it’s important to set up systems to keep your content fresh.
 We recommend starting with the following:
• Add verified properties — verified properties ensure that the information in your knowledge hub is accurate and trustworthy. Implement a process where subject matter experts review and approve content on a regular cadence. They’ll get notifications when their content is about to expire.
• Create an “admin” view — an admin view allows administrators to oversee and manage the content more efficiently. This view can include filters and sorting options to quickly identify outdated or inaccurate information.

Chunk 646:
Add verified properties — verified properties ensure that the information in your knowledge hub is accurate and trustworthy. Implement a process where subject matter experts review and approve content on a regular cadence. They’ll get notifications when their content is about to expire.
 Create an “admin” view — an admin view allows administrators to oversee and manage the content more efficiently. This view can include filters and sorting options to quickly identify outdated or inaccurate information.

Chunk 647:
• Keep content in a single database — Centralizing your content in one database prevents information sprawl and makes it easier to maintain. This structure helps in keeping the knowledge hub organized and ensures that users can find information quickly. Learn more about how Notion AI finds answers here.
• Utilize AI autofill — AI can summarize or extract information from all of your wiki entries at once based on a single prompt. This can help to save time by generating answers based on text in a page, without you having to read through each one manually.

Chunk 648:
Keep content in a single database — Centralizing your content in one database prevents information sprawl and makes it easier to maintain. This structure helps in keeping the knowledge hub organized and ensures that users can find information quickly. Learn more about how Notion AI finds answers here.
 Utilize AI autofill — AI can summarize or extract information from all of your wiki entries at once based on a single prompt. This can help to save time by generating answers based on text in a page, without you having to read through each one manually.
Tips & tricks for growing your hub over time

Chunk 649:
• Add an upvote button — Encourage users to interact with content by giving it an upvote. This helps prioritize valuable information. Learn more about database buttons here.
• Create a feedback database — Set up a database to collect and manage user feedback about the knowledge hub itself to assist with continuous improvement.
 Add an upvote button — Encourage users to interact with content by giving it an upvote. This helps prioritize valuable information. Learn more about database buttons here.
 Create a feedback database — Set up a database to collect and manage user feedback about the knowledge hub itself to assist with continuous improvement.

Chunk 650:
• Use page analytics — these can help you see which what content is getting the most use and prioritize updates accordingly.
• Schedule regular content reviews — set up a recurring schedule to review and update the information in your knowledge hub. This ensures that the content remains relevant and accurate over time.
 Use page analytics — these can help you see which what content is getting the most use and prioritize updates accordingly.
 Schedule regular content reviews — set up a recurring schedule to review and update the information in your knowledge hub. This ensures that the content remains relevant and accurate over time.

Chunk 651:
Building and maintaining an AI-powered knowledge hub in Notion is an ongoing process that requires careful planning, organization, and continuous improvement. By following the steps outlined in this guide, you can create a valuable resource that not only helps your team access the information they need but also leverages the power of AI to keep your documentation up-to-date and easily searchable. Remember, the key to a successful knowledge hub is engagement and feedback from your users, so make sure to encourage interaction and continuously refine your content based on their needs.
 Additional resources as you build your knowledge hub
• Get to know Notion AI better with our collection of AI-related guides.

Chunk 652:
• If you’re an IT admin who is new to Notion, the ultimate quickstart guide to Notion for Enterprise might be a good primer on all things people, sharing, and security.
• For builders, Notion Academy is a one-stop shop for learning everything you need to know. Find courses about scaling your team, managing an enterprise workspace, and more.
• Finally, understanding how Q&A finds answers can help you get better results — read the specifics in this guide.

An AI-powered knowledge hub can save hours for your team every single day. Learn how to build, roll out, and maintain your AI-powered knowledge hub in Notion.
• Set your hub strategy and get stakeholder alignment

Chunk 657:
• Start with a teamspace, fill it with templates
• Selecting use-case specific trackers
• Move, import, and create your content
• Polish and publish
• Share your hub with your team
• Announce your hub, train your team
• Grow & maintain your hub
• Tips & tricks for growing your hub over time
 Employees often struggle to find the information they need, leading to inefficiencies in your work and theirs — and costing your business in big ways.

Chunk 658:
We dreamed up with our customers of a better way to create and find your knowledge, and it's called an AI knowledge hub. These hubs can help you empower employees to find and understand information they need to do their jobs.
 Whether you’re onboarding new employees, creating single source of truth for your engineering documentation, supporting a customer experience team at scale, or looking for a low-lift way to deflect internal IT tickets, a knowledge hub with AI Q&A will help you do it.
 In this guide, we’ll cover everything you need to know to build, roll out, and maintain your knowledge hub.
Set your hub strategy and get stakeholder alignment

Chunk 659:
While you might be eager to dive into your knowledge hub build-out (as are we), it’s important to start with a plan. A successful AI implementation includes a clear strategic goal, identifying who will use your knowledge hub, what information they will find, and why you’re investing in building one at all.
 Consider the following tasks before you embark on building your knowledge hub in Notion:
• Identify who will use your hub — Determine the primary users of your knowledge hub. This could include employees, departments, or specific teams that will rely on the hub for information.

Chunk 660:
• Determine key stakeholders — Identify the people who will have a significant influence on the development and success of your knowledge hub. This is likely a group of folks including a Notion champion, a knowledge manager, an IT admin, and other folks that make sense within the context of your org (like bizops, or a chief of staff where relevant).
• Assess current state and gather user feedback — Collect input from potential users to understand their needs and expectations for the knowledge hub. Learn where your audience is finding (or not finding) answers to their questions, and determine how long it’s currently taking them to do so. Your goal throughout this project will be to reduce that time spent searching.

Chunk 661:
• Find your documentation and create a content map for future state — Next, dive into your docs. What questions can be answered with current documentation? Do you need to write new docs? Update old ones? Write this all down, you’ll come back to it later on.
• Set a measurable ROI goal — At this point, we hope you have a sense of the pain points in your current workflows. That means it’s time to set a tangible goal for your upcoming project! Notion AI can help teams save significant time from searching for information and increase their overall productivity and satisfaction at work. Use the Notion AI ROI calculator to set a goal for your team.

Chunk 662:
Identify who will use your hub — Determine the primary users of your knowledge hub. This could include employees, departments, or specific teams that will rely on the hub for information.
 Determine key stakeholders — Identify the people who will have a significant influence on the development and success of your knowledge hub. This is likely a group of folks including a Notion champion, a knowledge manager, an IT admin, and other folks that make sense within the context of your org (like bizops, or a chief of staff where relevant).

Chunk 663:
Assess current state and gather user feedback — Collect input from potential users to understand their needs and expectations for the knowledge hub. Learn where your audience is finding (or not finding) answers to their questions, and determine how long it’s currently taking them to do so. Your goal throughout this project will be to reduce that time spent searching.
 Find your documentation and create a content map for future state — Next, dive into your docs. What questions can be answered with current documentation? Do you need to write new docs? Update old ones? Write this all down, you’ll come back to it later on.

Chunk 664:
Set a measurable ROI goal — At this point, we hope you have a sense of the pain points in your current workflows. That means it’s time to set a tangible goal for your upcoming project! Notion AI can help teams save significant time from searching for information and increase their overall productivity and satisfaction at work. Use the Notion AI ROI calculator to set a goal for your team.
 The rest of this guide will walk you through the steps your team needs to take to transition from your current state to your new knowledge hub in Notion. Happy building!
 We’re here to help!
 Reach out to our sales team for support to start building your strategy with an experienced partner.
Create a space for your hub

Chunk 665:
Your team does its best work when everyone on it has access to the information they need to do their jobs, when they need it. Just like the entrance to your physical office sets the stage for a productive working day, your knowledge hub home-base sets (appropriately) high expectations for what your users will find in Notion.
Start with a teamspace, fill it with templates

Chunk 666:
Begin by setting up a dedicated teamspace for your knowledge hub. This space will serve as the central location where all knowledge hub templates and resources are stored. Make sure it is easily accessible to all team members who will be contributing to or using the hub, either by making it a “default” teamspace (so members are added automatically), or by setting the permissions to open such that anyone can join.
 Once your teamspace is setup, you can begin building the architecture for your hub. For now, focus just on how users will navigate the hub. At a minimum, your knowledge hub template will include the following components.
 Skip this step with templates for every team
 We created best-in-class templates for your knowledge:

Chunk 667:
• Onboarding hub
• Customer support hub
• IT trouble shooting hub, or
• Legal and compliance hub
 Engineering hub
 Onboarding hub
 Customer support hub
 IT trouble shooting hub, or
 Legal and compliance hub
 To use these templates, duplicate them into your workspace, and move each page into the sidebar of your newly created teamspace. Then, read on for guidance on filling your hub with content and rolling it out to your team.

Chunk 668:
• Top level page — you’ll want to utilize a single, top-level page to act as a landing place for your knowledge hub. This is a place for your team to get a birds-eye-view of the information in your hub, and an understanding of how they can use it. It’s also a great place to mention pages that you want to draw attention to, or request feedback (more on that later).

Chunk 669:
• Wiki database (part of your top level page) — once your top-level page is established, you can use the “Turn to Wiki” button in the ... menu on the top left of your Notion page to create a new view for organizing sub-pages. Adding pages into a database will help immensely as you organize and scale your knowledge hub thanks to properties like tags and verification. Learn more about wiki databases here →

Chunk 670:
Top level page — you’ll want to utilize a single, top-level page to act as a landing place for your knowledge hub. This is a place for your team to get a birds-eye-view of the information in your hub, and an understanding of how they can use it. It’s also a great place to mention pages that you want to draw attention to, or request feedback (more on that later).

Chunk 671:
Wiki database (part of your top level page) — once your top-level page is established, you can use the “Turn to Wiki” button in the ... menu on the top left of your Notion page to create a new view for organizing sub-pages. Adding pages into a database will help immensely as you organize and scale your knowledge hub thanks to properties like tags and verification. Learn more about wiki databases here →
• FAQs — the FAQ database serves two important purposes as you build out your knowledge hub. First, it creates a repository for key bits of information that are otherwise buried in long documents. Second, it helps AI more easily find the answers to commonly asked questions, ensuring your team gets what they need as quickly as possible.

Chunk 672:
• AI Q&A — make sure you see the AI icon in the bottom right hand corner of your app (if not, check to make sure you have AI enabled in “settings”). This is where you and your end users will go to ask questions about the content in the knowledge hub.
 FAQs — the FAQ database serves two important purposes as you build out your knowledge hub. First, it creates a repository for key bits of information that are otherwise buried in long documents. Second, it helps AI more easily find the answers to commonly asked questions, ensuring your team gets what they need as quickly as possible.

• Use-case specific trackers — These are tailored to meet the specific needs of different teams within your organization — like a product feedback tracker, or IT request system. They help in gaining insight into workflows, tracking progress, and ensuring that everyone has access to the necessary information.

Polish and publish

Chunk 685:
• Then, add teamspace Members — Teamspace members contribute to the knowledge base by adding new information, updating existing content, and actively engaging with the AI-powered features. They are also the primary consumers of the knowledge. Give them “Can edit” permissions to edit existing pages and create new pages within the teamspace.

Chunk 686:
Add teamspace owners — Teamspace owners act as the primary knowledge curators. They are responsible for the overall organization, structure, and maintenance of the knowledge hub. You’ll want to give them Full Access so that they can create, edit, and delete all pages within the teamspace. As teamspace owners, they’ll also be able to adjust teamspace settings, invite/remove members, and manage permissions.
 Then, add teamspace Members — Teamspace members contribute to the knowledge base by adding new information, updating existing content, and actively engaging with the AI-powered features. They are also the primary consumers of the knowledge. Give them “Can edit” permissions to edit existing pages and create new pages within the teamspace.

Chunk 687:
Teamspaces are Notion’s solution to complex permission requirements
 Click to expand
Announce your hub, train your team
 Now that everyone has access to your knowledge hub, it’s time to announce your hub and train your team. You’ll know what announcement channels tend to work best for your company (and we have some tips below, too!), but dont forget to teach your audience how to use your new tool.
 To start, make sure your end users have the resources they need to navigate your knowledge hub. In your announcement comms, focus on helping users learn how to navigate using the sidebar, and how to get answers about work content faster with Q&A.

Chunk 688:
Start emphasizing the value of Notion AI, even demo-ing some questions that users can find the answers to within your new and improved knowledge hub.
 Give your team the resources they need
 Click to expand
Focus on internal communications
 If a resource is created, and no one knows about it, does it even exist? Internal comms are a vital component of your rollout strategy, and you should expect to spend a few weeks (up to a few months) showing off your new hub. Here’s just a few ideas that have helped our customers:

Chunk 689:
• Start with a pilot group — for a bigger roll out, consider starting with a pilot. A diverse pilot group across departments can help test the knowledge hub and gather feedback on usability, content, and AI effectiveness before a larger launch.
• Preview your hub in a team meeting or all hands — schedule a dedicated session to walk through the knowledge hub, highlight key features, and demonstrate how to use it effectively. This ensures everyone is familiar with the new resource.
• Send written communications about your hub — draft an email or internal memo that outlines the purpose of the knowledge hub, provides usage instructions, and includes a link to access it. This helps to reinforce the hub's importance and utility.

Chunk 690:
• Stop answering questions — this is the hardest, and most important component of a successful knowledge hub rollout. In order to build new habits, you’ll want to continuously re-direct your question-asking colleagues to your new and improved knowledge hub. Gently remind them to ask their question to Notion AI before asking in your slack channel or DMs.
 Start with a pilot group — for a bigger roll out, consider starting with a pilot. A diverse pilot group across departments can help test the knowledge hub and gather feedback on usability, content, and AI effectiveness before a larger launch.

Chunk 691:
Preview your hub in a team meeting or all hands — schedule a dedicated session to walk through the knowledge hub, highlight key features, and demonstrate how to use it effectively. This ensures everyone is familiar with the new resource.
 Send written communications about your hub — draft an email or internal memo that outlines the purpose of the knowledge hub, provides usage instructions, and includes a link to access it. This helps to reinforce the hub's importance and utility.

Chunk 692:
Stop answering questions — this is the hardest, and most important component of a successful knowledge hub rollout. In order to build new habits, you’ll want to continuously re-direct your question-asking colleagues to your new and improved knowledge hub. Gently remind them to ask their question to Notion AI before asking in your slack channel or DMs.
Grow & maintain your hub
 Think of your wiki as a garden. Just as a garden needs regular tending to flourish, your knowledge hub requires continuous updates and care. Plant new ideas, prune outdated information, and nurture the content to keep it vibrant and useful for everyone who visits.
Keep your content fresh

Chunk 693:
One of the worst detractors to the long-term health of your knowledge hub is stale or outdated content. That’s why it’s important to set up systems to keep your content fresh.
 We recommend starting with the following:
• Add verified properties — verified properties ensure that the information in your knowledge hub is accurate and trustworthy. Implement a process where subject matter experts review and approve content on a regular cadence. They’ll get notifications when their content is about to expire.
• Create an “admin” view — an admin view allows administrators to oversee and manage the content more efficiently. This view can include filters and sorting options to quickly identify outdated or inaccurate information.

Chunk 694:
Add verified properties — verified properties ensure that the information in your knowledge hub is accurate and trustworthy. Implement a process where subject matter experts review and approve content on a regular cadence. They’ll get notifications when their content is about to expire.
 Create an “admin” view — an admin view allows administrators to oversee and manage the content more efficiently. This view can include filters and sorting options to quickly identify outdated or inaccurate information.

Chunk 695:
• Keep content in a single database — Centralizing your content in one database prevents information sprawl and makes it easier to maintain. This structure helps in keeping the knowledge hub organized and ensures that users can find information quickly. Learn more about how Notion AI finds answers here.
• Utilize AI autofill — AI can summarize or extract information from all of your wiki entries at once based on a single prompt. This can help to save time by generating answers based on text in a page, without you having to read through each one manually.

Chunk 696:
Keep content in a single database — Centralizing your content in one database prevents information sprawl and makes it easier to maintain. This structure helps in keeping the knowledge hub organized and ensures that users can find information quickly. Learn more about how Notion AI finds answers here.
 Utilize AI autofill — AI can summarize or extract information from all of your wiki entries at once based on a single prompt. This can help to save time by generating answers based on text in a page, without you having to read through each one manually.
Tips & tricks for growing your hub over time

Chunk 697:
• Add an upvote button — Encourage users to interact with content by giving it an upvote. This helps prioritize valuable information. Learn more about database buttons here.
• Create a feedback database — Set up a database to collect and manage user feedback about the knowledge hub itself to assist with continuous improvement.
 Add an upvote button — Encourage users to interact with content by giving it an upvote. This helps prioritize valuable information. Learn more about database buttons here.
 Create a feedback database — Set up a database to collect and manage user feedback about the knowledge hub itself to assist with continuous improvement.

Chunk 698:
• Use page analytics — these can help you see which what content is getting the most use and prioritize updates accordingly.
• Schedule regular content reviews — set up a recurring schedule to review and update the information in your knowledge hub. This ensures that the content remains relevant and accurate over time.
 Use page analytics — these can help you see which what content is getting the most use and prioritize updates accordingly.
 Schedule regular content reviews — set up a recurring schedule to review and update the information in your knowledge hub. This ensures that the content remains relevant and accurate over time.

Chunk 699:
Building and maintaining an AI-powered knowledge hub in Notion is an ongoing process that requires careful planning, organization, and continuous improvement. By following the steps outlined in this guide, you can create a valuable resource that not only helps your team access the information they need but also leverages the power of AI to keep your documentation up-to-date and easily searchable. Remember, the key to a successful knowledge hub is engagement and feedback from your users, so make sure to encourage interaction and continuously refine your content based on their needs.
 Additional resources as you build your knowledge hub
• Get to know Notion AI better with our collection of AI-related guides.

Chunk 700:
• If you’re an IT admin who is new to Notion, the ultimate quickstart guide to Notion for Enterprise might be a good primer on all things people, sharing, and security.
• For builders, Notion Academy is a one-stop shop for learning everything you need to know. Find courses about scaling your team, managing an enterprise workspace, and more.
• Finally, understanding how Q&A finds answers can help you get better results — read the specifics in this guide.

Learn how to create and edit pages in Notion by making a simple personal task list.
 Every page you create in Notion is a fresh canvas where you can add whatever content you want.

Chunk 714:
When you open a new page, just start typing. You’ll notice other features fade away so you can focus on getting your thoughts on the page.
• Create sections using headings like H1 , H2 or H3.
• Highlight any text to bring up a menu of options and tools. From here you can style your text, add a hyperlink and more.
• Or, format text using markdown syntax to style without ever moving your mouse.Add a toggle list to hide less important information.Try columns to split up content.Add a divider to help organize your sections.
• Add a toggle list to hide less important information.
• Try columns to split up content.
• Add a divider to help organize your sections.
 Create sections using headings like H1 , H2 or H3.

Chunk 715:
Highlight any text to bring up a menu of options and tools. From here you can style your text, add a hyperlink and more.
 Or, format text using markdown syntax to style without ever moving your mouse.
• Add a toggle list to hide less important information.
• Try columns to split up content.
• Add a divider to help organize your sections.

Blocks are the basic unit of construction in Notion. Learn how 500+ block types come together to create beautiful, custom tools.

Chunk 719:
Blocks are the way you build in Notion. Everything that sits on a page is a block including text, images, and tables.
 You can mix and match different blocks to create unique pages and tools for your team.
 There are six main block categories (and over 500 blocks types) in Notion:
• Database
• Media
• Advanced blocks
• In-line options
 Basic blocks
 Database
 Media
 Embeds
 Advanced blocks
 In-line options

 Your AI-enabled workspace becomes more powerful when it’s connected, comprehensive, and up-to-date — create systems to get the most out of your investment.
How to build a connected workspace

Chunk 732:
Welcome to our course on building a connected workspace! Your AI-enabled workspace becomes more powerful when it’s connected, comprehensive, and up-to-date — here’s everything you’ll want to learn to get there.
Importing Data
 Start centralizing your workflows by surveying your existing tools and importing data in Notion.
What’s in a connected workspace?
 The ideal connected workspace organizes specific types of knowledge. To understand and apply these concepts in practice, explore the sidebar and create a new teamspace.
Docs and meetings
 Dive deeper into two types of living knowledge — docs and meeting notes — and consider how you could customize them for your team.
Wikis and FAQs

Chunk 733:
Learn how to use Wikis and FAQs to house your team’s lasting knowledge, as well as tactics to help establish trust in these resources.
Projects
 Learn how to create, manage, and customize projects in your workspace.
Relations and Rollups
 Learn how to use Notion's relations and rollups features to connect and view information across databases.
Connected Properties
 Learn how to integrate Notion with other tools using connected properties.
Linked views
 Linked database views let you see subsets of your knowledge in new contexts. Learn how to create linked views for your docs, meetings, and more.
Synced blocks

Chunk 734:
Within a page you can use features like synced blocks and page mentions to connect information in a more informal way. Learn how to create and use these features.
Connected workspace for IT teams
 See how building a connected workspace can come together to ease the burden on foundational teams within your company.
Connected workspace for GTM teams
 See how building a connected workspace can come together to keep even the most complicated launch timelines in check.
Connected workspace for Engineering teams
 See how building a connected workspace can come together to keep all of the steps of your triage process in sync.
Sharing your workspace

Chunk 735:
Learn how to effectively share and access knowledge in Notion, including how to create and find content using the sidebar, search, and Q&A.
Creating a culture of documentation
 Learn how to cultivate a culture of documentation in your workspace to maintain your connected workspace’s value.
Getting started with Notion AI
 Learn how to use artificial intelligence to improve writing, simplify tasks, and generate text from scratch.
 What is artificial intelligence?

Start centralizing your workflows by surveying your existing tools and importing data in Notion.

Chunk 742:
• The first step to building a connected workspace is surveying your team's tool stack and categorizing tools into two categories:Replace: Docs and wiki tools, project management tools, AI writers Integrate: Specialized tools, like Figma, Slack, and Git Hub
• Replace: Docs and wiki tools, project management tools, AI writers
• Integrate: Specialized tools, like Figma, Slack, and Git Hub
• For tools in the “replace” category, start by importing content Start an import in Notion through the "import" button on the bottom left of your sidebar.Use AI to query your workspace and quickly get answers to your questions after importing content.
• Start an import in Notion through the "import" button on the bottom left of your sidebar.

The ideal connected workspace organizes specific types of knowledge. To understand and apply these concepts in practice, explore the sidebar and create a new teamspace.

Chunk 748:
• Your workspace should have two kinds of teamspaces — General (for everyone, company-wide) and team-specific (one for each team… marketing, product, etc.)
• Each kind of teamspace houses different knowledge types.General teamspace → Docs, Meetings, Wiki, and FAQs Team teamspace’s → Wiki, FAQs, Project trackers
• General teamspace → Docs, Meetings, Wiki, and FAQs
• Team teamspace’s → Wiki, FAQs, Project trackers
• Databases are the key to organizing and managing different types of knowledge.
 Your workspace should have two kinds of teamspaces — General (for everyone, company-wide) and team-specific (one for each team… marketing, product, etc.)
 Each kind of teamspace houses different knowledge types.

Chunk 749:
• General teamspace → Docs, Meetings, Wiki, and FAQs
• Team teamspace’s → Wiki, FAQs, Project trackers
 General teamspace → Docs, Meetings, Wiki, and FAQs
 Team teamspace’s → Wiki, FAQs, Project trackers
 Databases are the key to organizing and managing different types of knowledge.

How to build a connected workspace

Chunk 753:
Welcome to our course on building a connected workspace! Your AI-enabled workspace becomes more powerful when it’s connected, comprehensive, and up-to-date — here’s everything you’ll want to learn to get there.
Importing Data
 Start centralizing your workflows by surveying your existing tools and importing data in Notion.
What’s in a connected workspace?
 The ideal connected workspace organizes specific types of knowledge. To understand and apply these concepts in practice, explore the sidebar and create a new teamspace.
Docs and meetings
 Dive deeper into two types of living knowledge — docs and meeting notes — and consider how you could customize them for your team.
Wikis and FAQs

Chunk 754:
Learn how to use Wikis and FAQs to house your team’s lasting knowledge, as well as tactics to help establish trust in these resources.
Projects
 Learn how to create, manage, and customize projects in your workspace.
Relations and Rollups
 Learn how to use Notion's relations and rollups features to connect and view information across databases.
Connected Properties
 Learn how to integrate Notion with other tools using connected properties.
Linked views
 Linked database views let you see subsets of your knowledge in new contexts. Learn how to create linked views for your docs, meetings, and more.
Synced blocks

Chunk 755:
Within a page you can use features like synced blocks and page mentions to connect information in a more informal way. Learn how to create and use these features.
Connected workspace for IT teams
 See how building a connected workspace can come together to ease the burden on foundational teams within your company.
Connected workspace for GTM teams
 See how building a connected workspace can come together to keep even the most complicated launch timelines in check.
Connected workspace for Engineering teams
 See how building a connected workspace can come together to keep all of the steps of your triage process in sync.
Sharing your workspace

Chunk 756:
Learn how to effectively share and access knowledge in Notion, including how to create and find content using the sidebar, search, and Q&A.
Creating a culture of documentation
 Learn how to cultivate a culture of documentation in your workspace to maintain your connected workspace’s value.
Getting started with Notion AI
 Learn how to use artificial intelligence to improve writing, simplify tasks, and generate text from scratch.

Explain what artificial intelligence is and how to access it in Notion.
 This course covers three main ideas that Notion AI enables: improving writing, increasing work efficiency, and generating new text.

Chunk 768:
• Improving writing with AI — Notion AI can help with spelling and grammar mistakes, shorten paragraphs, clarify technical terms, and more.
• Increasing work efficiency with AI —Notion AI can summarize and extract insights from various documents, such as research papers, product requirement docs, tech specs, or news articles.
• Generating new text with AI — Notion AI can help with writer's block by brainstorming ideas and content drafts. Ask AI for anything, and continue asking follow up prompts until you’re satisfied with the output
 Improving writing with AI — Notion AI can help with spelling and grammar mistakes, shorten paragraphs, clarify technical terms, and more.

Chunk 769:
Increasing work efficiency with AI —Notion AI can summarize and extract insights from various documents, such as research papers, product requirement docs, tech specs, or news articles.
 Generating new text with AI — Notion AI can help with writer's block by brainstorming ideas and content drafts. Ask AI for anything, and continue asking follow up prompts until you’re satisfied with the output
 How does artificial intelligence work?
 The computer finds patterns in a large set of data called training data to make a model.
 The computer tests the model by asking a question it already knows the answer to and analyzing how accurate its answer is, using test data.
 With more inputs and training data, it learns and improves the model over time.

Chunk 770:
Read more about how artificial intelligence works, as well as its current limitations, here.
 Assignment
 To use Notion AI, all you have to do is navigate to a new line and press the space key. If you’re out of responses, learn more about AI pricing here.
Improve writing with Notion AI
 Explore ways that AI can help improve your writing. Then, put it into practice by editing a blog post with AI.
