Use AI to extract information from text by summarizing and pulling action items from a meeting transcript.

Chunk 777:
Notion AI can perform time-consuming tasks such as summarizing notes, distilling research, and translating documents in seconds. This is achieved through three key actions:
• Summarizing: highlight any text and Notion AI will summarize it. This feature is useful for internal documents, web articles, and more.
• Extracting insights: Notion AI can quickly analyze text-based data and identify common themes or patterns, allowing efficient learning from the data.
• Generating text with page context: Notion AI can transform scrappy notes into coherent sentences like for performance reviews, job descriptions, and more.

Chunk 778:
Summarizing: highlight any text and Notion AI will summarize it. This feature is useful for internal documents, web articles, and more.
 Extracting insights: Notion AI can quickly analyze text-based data and identify common themes or patterns, allowing efficient learning from the data.
 Generating text with page context: Notion AI can transform scrappy notes into coherent sentences like for performance reviews, job descriptions, and more.
 Add AI blocks to Notion pages by typing /ai to incorporate custom prompts into your meeting notes templates and more.
• Add a Summary block for quick summaries of any document.
• Use Action items to keep team members accountable.

Chunk 779:
• Try Custom block for any other AI prompt that you’d like to save and use over again.
 Add a Summary block for quick summaries of any document.
 Use Action items to keep team members accountable.
 Try Custom block for any other AI prompt that you’d like to save and use over again.
 Assignment
 Use this meeting summaries template to get started with AI blocks in your workspace.
How to write good AI prompts
 Learn how to generate text from scratch using Notion AI, with a focus on writing good prompts and refining output.

Chunk 794:

Build a website starting with a template, understand the blocks that can be used, and customize your Site to suit your needs.

Chunk 803:
• Notion allows you to create a website quickly and easily without any coding required. You can build a landing page, portfolio, or help center using Notion’s powerful building blocks.
• Notion offers a variety of pre-built site templates to help you get started quickly. For example, the Personal Website template can be customized extensively.
• To personalize your site, you can embed visual elements like photographs or videos, add custom sections using headings, and use Notion’s AI writing capabilities to craft content.
 Notion allows you to create a website quickly and easily without any coding required. You can build a landing page, portfolio, or help center using Notion’s powerful building blocks.

Chunk 804:
Notion offers a variety of pre-built site templates to help you get started quickly. For example, the Personal Website template can be customized extensively.
 To personalize your site, you can embed visual elements like photographs or videos, add custom sections using headings, and use Notion’s AI writing capabilities to craft content.
 Assignment
 For those looking for a quick start, explore the pre-built site templates in Notion's template gallery.
Publishing Notion pages to the web
 Publish a Notion page to the web in just a few clicks, and learn how to configure basic settings in the publish menu.

Publish a Notion page to the web in just a few clicks, and learn how to configure basic settings in the publish menu.

Chunk 808:
• Publish a Notion page to the web by navigating to the Share menu, selecting the Publish tab, and clicking the Publish button.
• Configure basic settings in the publish menu, including setting up a custom domain, enabling SEO indexing, and setting link expirations.
• Once published, the Notion page will have a public URL that can be shared with others, making it accessible to anyone on the web. You can change the domain in the “Settings” menu.
• Any changes made to the Notion page will automatically reflect on the public version, ensuring the content is always up-to-date.
 Publish a Notion page to the web by navigating to the Share menu, selecting the Publish tab, and clicking the Publish button.

Chunk 809:
Configure basic settings in the publish menu, including setting up a custom domain, enabling SEO indexing, and setting link expirations.
 Once published, the Notion page will have a public URL that can be shared with others, making it accessible to anyone on the web. You can change the domain in the “Settings” menu.
 Any changes made to the Notion page will automatically reflect on the public version, ensuring the content is always up-to-date.

 Personalize your Notion site with visual customizations and editable link previews in the "Site customizations" menu.

 Set up your Notion project and add tasks. Then, add properties to build custom views, connect Git Hub, manage work in sprints, and more.
Projects: Introduction

Chunk 823:
Welcome to our project management course! Learn about Notion Projects, and everything you’ll cover in this course.
Create a project plan
 Create a proposal document that will help you align all stakeholders and set the foundation for a successful project plan using Notion.
Plan projects with AI
 Show you how to leverage the power of Notion AI to build a project plan.
Add projects & tasks
 Add a projects & tasks database to your workspace and streamline your project management processes.
Create a project tracker
 Create a project tracker in your new template and start adding content.
Add tasks to a project
 Add tasks and subtasks to your project plan.
Assign tasks

Chunk 824:
Assign tasks to your team members and add task details to keep everyone on the same page.
Organize tasks
 Personalize your project management system by adding suggested properties to your tasks and projects to power create custom views and work the way you want to.
AI Autofill property
 Use AI to automate tedious information gathering processes and unlock more time to focus on impactful work.
Views for projects
 Learn about custom database layouts and views to bring your project management process to the next level.
Database templates for tasks
 Use and create templates to fill out task details, and help requesting teams do the same.
Connect work with relations

Chunk 825:
Learn how relations and rollups can organize and connect your projects, tasks, docs, and meeting notes for more streamlined work.
Manage tasks in sprints
 Manage sprints in Notion using the beta Sprints feature.
Unique ID property
 Use a unique IDs property to more efficiently track tasks and reduce duplicate entries.
Git Hub property
 Integrate Git Hub with your tasks database in Notion.
Buttons
 Build buttons to let teammates submit requests and bug reports to your project and task databases.
Scaling your team
 Everything you need to know about content management and sharing in Notion. Start with a deep dive into the sidebar and page sharing, then work your way up to teamspaces and inherited permissions.

Chunk 826:
Scaling your team: Introduction

Chunk 832:
• We recommend teams make use of one centralized “Docs” database for managing project proposals, PRDs, tech specs, and more.Later, you’ll learn how to connect these to projects and tasks.

• Create a new page in docs with the blue New button in the top right hand corner.
• Consider using bullet points to get ideas on paper, and AI to polish those ideas into full sentences.

Show you how to leverage the power of Notion AI to build a project plan.

Chunk 836:
• Three ways to use AI to help with your project plan Generate content from scratch with Notion AI by asking for a list of tasks needed to complete your project Expand previously drafted bullet points by highlighting text and asking AI to "make longer".Clean up and improve writing by asking AI to simplify writing lengthy sections.
• Expand previously drafted bullet points by highlighting text and asking AI to "make longer".
• Clean up and improve writing by asking AI to simplify writing lengthy sections.
 Three ways to use AI to help with your project plan

Chunk 837:
• Expand previously drafted bullet points by highlighting text and asking AI to "make longer".
• Clean up and improve writing by asking AI to simplify writing lengthy sections.
 Generate content from scratch with Notion AI by asking for a list of tasks needed to complete your project

 Clean up and improve writing by asking AI to simplify writing lengthy sections.

 Everything you need to know about content management and sharing in Notion. Start with a deep dive into the sidebar and page sharing, then work your way up to teamspaces and inherited permissions.
Scaling your team: Introduction

Chunk 850:
Welcome to Notion’s course on scaling your team!
Scaling your team: Page sharing
 Learn how to share pages in Notion with other individuals in your workspace, or publicly as websites.
Scaling your team: Sidebar
 Learn how to find pages using the sidebar and customize it to meet your needs.
Scaling your team: Office manual
 Apply learnings from past videos to build and share an office manual in your team’s knowledge base.
Scaling your team: Database templates
 Learn how to build and use database templates to streamline repetitive tasks.
Scaling your team: Advanced database properties
 Advanced database properties can help managers and admins alike make sense of large databases — learn how to use them in your org.

Chunk 851:
Scaling your team: Updates database
 Apply what you’ve learned about database templates and advanced properties to create an organized, scalable updates database for your company.
Scale your team: Building teamspaces
 Create teamspaces and explain best ways to construct a sidebar for teams by comparing and contrasting methods of sidebar organization.
Scale your team: Permissions
 Explain page sharing inheritance by creating a new employee onboarding resource with different access levels for different pages.
Scaling your team: Team wiki
 Build a skeleton for a large team’s wiki using what you’ve learned so far.
Using data
 Work with large data sets in Notion including native databases, 1st party integrations, and link previews.

Learn how to share pages in Notion with other individuals in your workspace, or publicly as websites.

Chunk 858:
Any pages in the teamspaces section will be accessible to everyone in that teamspace. This can be useful for transparency and keeping everyone on the same page.
• There are sections in your sidebar:Teamspaces: pages shared with everyone in a teamspace.Shared: pages shared by or with you, but not everyone.Private: pages only you can see.
• Teamspaces: pages shared with everyone in a teamspace.
• Shared: pages shared by or with you, but not everyone.
• Private: pages only you can see.
• To share a private page with individual members, use the Share button.
• You can Favorite items to have them appear at the top of your sidebar.
 There are sections in your sidebar:
• Teamspaces: pages shared with everyone in a teamspace.

Chunk 859:
• Shared: pages shared by or with you, but not everyone.
• Private: pages only you can see.
 Teamspaces: pages shared with everyone in a teamspace.
 Shared: pages shared by or with you, but not everyone.
 Private: pages only you can see.
 To share a private page with individual members, use the Share button.
 You can Favorite items to have them appear at the top of your sidebar.
 Assignment
 Shared one on one docs are a great way for managers and reports to stay connected. Get started with the template.

Learn how to find pages using the sidebar and customize it to meet your needs.
 In Notion, pages can house other pages. You can see nested pages by clicking the dropdown on any page in your sidebar.

Chunk 863:
• All content in Notion, lives on a page.
• To tell where a page lives, you can look at the breadcrumbs at the top of the page.
• We recommend having a company operating systems page and a page in the sidebar for every major function on your team.Like marketing, design, or engineering. Within those pages, you can further categorize as needed.
• Like marketing, design, or engineering. Within those pages, you can further categorize as needed.
 All content in Notion, lives on a page.
 To tell where a page lives, you can look at the breadcrumbs at the top of the page.
 We recommend having a company operating systems page and a page in the sidebar for every major function on your team.

Chunk 864:
• Like marketing, design, or engineering. Within those pages, you can further categorize as needed.
 Like marketing, design, or engineering. Within those pages, you can further categorize as needed.
 Assignment
 Keep marketing and brand assets organized with this template.

Using data: Introduction
 Welcome to Notion’s course on using data!
Using data: Intro to databases

Chunk 875:
Get started with databases, one of Notion’s most powerful features for organization, by creating a content calendar for a marketing team.
Using data: Database views
 Learn how to create new layouts on databases, and sort and filter data to see exactly what you need.
Using data: Meeting notes
 With your new database skills, architect a meeting notes database your whole team can operate from.
Using data: Embeds
 Learn how to use embeds in Notion and incorporate Loom videos into a project plan.
Using data: Link previews
 Authenticate and use link previews and learn the difference between this feature and classic embeds.
Using data: Onboarding knowledge base

Chunk 876:
Create a one-stop-shop for all new hire information that pulls in important information from all of the tools your team is using.
Using data: Automations
 Install and use connections by creating a Typeform that auto-populates a Notion database.
Using data: Database sync
 Learn how to sync entire databases from tools like Jira and Git Hub to more centrally manage your work.
Using data: Integrated project management
 Create a living project hub for an upcoming product launch that combines Notion data, as well as data from third party apps.
Key setups for startup teams

Bust information silos and save valuable time and money by using Notion to replace common workplace tools. Here's just some of the tools and templates in Notion that can get your ideas off the ground.

Get started with databases, one of Notion’s most powerful features for organization, by creating a content calendar for a marketing team.

Chunk 883:
Databases might look like the typical spreadsheet, but they’re way more powerful. Unlike spreadsheets, databases can be filled with dynamic, relational data.
• Notion databases have many different properties, which can label pieces of data.Some unique property types include dates, emails, and URLs.These properties can be used to sort and filter the information in your database.
• Some unique property types include dates, emails, and URLs.
• These properties can be used to sort and filter the information in your database.
• Each database entry is also it’s own page.
• Database blocks can either be created in-line or as their own page.
 Notion databases have many different properties, which can label pieces of data.

Chunk 884:
• Some unique property types include dates, emails, and URLs.
• These properties can be used to sort and filter the information in your database.
 Some unique property types include dates, emails, and URLs.
 These properties can be used to sort and filter the information in your database.
 Each database entry is also it’s own page.
 Database blocks can either be created in-line or as their own page.
 Assignment
• Marketing teams can get started with the content calendar explored in this video.
• People teams might want to deploy a people directory.
• Engineering, product, and design teams might start with tasks and issues.
 Marketing teams can get started with the content calendar explored in this video.

Chunk 885:
People teams might want to deploy a people directory.
 Engineering, product, and design teams might start with tasks and issues.

Learn how to create new layouts on databases, and sort and filter data to see exactly what you need.

Chunk 888:
When you first create a database, you'll need to choose the layout of the default view. After this, you'll see the option to create additional views as tabs, with the + button. Your database can have as many views as you want!
• Give your view a name in the text box, and choose the type of layout you want.
• When you have multiple views, you'll see them listed across the top of your database as tabs.
 Give your view a name in the text box, and choose the type of layout you want.
 When you have multiple views, you'll see them listed across the top of your database as tabs.
 There are six different ways to visualize your content within a database. Here's a high level overview of each layout:
• Board
• Timeline
• List

Chunk 889:
• Gallery
 Table
 Board
 Timeline
 Calendar
 List
 Gallery
 Assignment
 Return to Notion to create views on any database. If you didn’t catch them in the last video, here’s some templates to get started:
• Marketing teams can get started with the content calendar explored in this video.
• People teams might want to deploy a people directory.
• Engineering, product, and design teams might start with tasks and issues.
 Marketing teams can get started with the content calendar explored in this video.
 People teams might want to deploy a people directory.
 Engineering, product, and design teams might start with
 tasks and issues.

• Log in
• Get Notion free
• Docs
• Wikis
• Calendar
• Sites
• Templates
 Bust information silos and save valuable time and money by using Notion to replace common workplace tools. Here's just some of the tools and templates in Notion that can get your ideas off the ground.
Get started with templates

Chunk 901:
Startup in a box is a one-stop-shop to get your startup up and running, and establish the documentation and operating systems that will support you through all stages of your company’s growth.
Build a team notes and docs database
 It's easy for team members to help build a living record of meetings and decisions, so that anyone can find the information they need. We'll show you where to keep notes, how to build the databases that store them, and how to create dynamic links between your notes & projects.
How to create OKRs

Chunk 902:
OKRs (objectives and key results) is a framework that helps teams set goals and keep track of their progress. With this system in Notion, you can create objectives and assign them specific key results, timelines, owners, and more.
How to build a help center
 Looking for an easy, no-frills way to set up a Help Center for your growing community of users? This video will show you how to build an external Help Center in Notion, and instantly publish it to the web.
How startups can create an easy-to-update job board
 Startups want to grow, but adding new roles or editing existing ones can be a bit of a pain. Notion solves this by giving teams a no code solution for hosting job listings and collecting applications.

Chunk 903:
Grow your startup with this applicant tracking system
 Organization is crucial in hiring. Use Notion to tag and filter candidates based on the teams they’d join, and where they’re at in the interview process.
How startups conduct user research
 Listening to users is an important part of growing your startup. With Notion, you can create a home for all your user interviews, categorize them, and connect them to your other relevant docs. Plus — you can even make templates to standardize the interview process for anyone on your team.
Build a wiki that scales
 Build a documentation system for a large company using databases and teamspaces. This course will move from creating pages to creating large databases and administrating teamspaces.

Chunk 904:
Creating a page

 Build a documentation system for a large company using databases and teamspaces. This course will move from creating pages to creating large databases and administrating teamspaces.
Creating a page

Chunk 926:
Learn how to get started by adding a new page to your Notion workspace.
Writing and editing basics
 Every Notion page is highly customizable - learn how to format text and other content blocks to your liking.
Navigating the sidebar
 Notion's sidebar has all the tools you need to organize your pages, add templates, access settings & more.
Docs & Wikis for large teams
 Are you using, or considering using Notion to operate a large organization? Notion can act as your team’s central knowledge hub — whether you’re already using Notion for documentation, or looking to get started, we thought we’d show you a few things that can make your workspace even more solid and efficient.
Creating links and backlinks

Chunk 927:
Connect your thoughts and ideas with links! Every time you make a link, Notion creates a backlink for you automatically. We'll show you how this can be helpful as you're managing tasks & projects, building a company wiki, or just taking some notes.
Notion for admins of large teams
 This video will prep you on the features available only to Notion workspace admins — from deciding how your teammates, as well as people external to your team, interact with your workspace, to allowing third-party integrations.
Teamspaces for admins
 Whether your team is 50 or 5,000, teamspaces can help ensure everyone has access to the right level of information that they need to do their job.
Organize information with databases

Chunk 928:
Databases are a powerful Notion feature that can unlock your toolmaking potential. Create databases, learn about layout types, and build databases for teams.
 Intro to databases

• Docs
• Wikis

• Sites
• Templates
 Databases are a powerful Notion feature that can unlock your toolmaking potential. Create databases, learn about layout types, and build databases for teams.
Intro to databases

Chunk 948:
Databases in Notion are collections of pages. Here, we'll introduce you to the general structure of a database, discuss the different menus and options, and deep dive into how to open and edit pages within a database. 🗃
Using database views
 Here, we'll introduce you to the different customization options and layouts that exist once you have a database set up in your workspace.
Timeline view
 Timeline is a type of Notion database that’s way more than a Gantt chart. It gives you complete flexibility to scope projects, adjust their timelines, and customize your workflow.
Table view

Chunk 949:
Tables are Notion's most traditional database view, but our tables are a lot more powerful than a grid with some rows and columns! Open each row as its own Notion page, or visualize in other database views.
Gallery view
 Galleries are Notion's most visual database view. Use them to showcase beautiful photos for mood boards, team directories, vacation photos and more.
List view
 Lists are Notion's most minimalist database view. All the power of a database, but without the visual clutter. Use them for meeting notes, journal entries, process documentation and more!
Board view

Chunk 950:
One of Notion's most powerful features, Boards are the best way to manage projects & tasks. Use them to group your databases by select, multiselect, and person properties.
Calendar view
 Calendars are a great way to visualize dates from any database in Notion. Use them for your company's social media planning, or add a calendar view to your product management databases.
Using database templates
 Instead of manually typing out the same structure and content for every new page, you can use database templates to automate your processes and save some time.
Using linked databases

Chunk 951:
Linked databases let you include synced copies of the same content across different pages. Use them to include a filtered view of team tasks in your meeting notes, or create a dashboard of tasks assigned to you from different databases.
Using advanced database filters
 Managing tasks and projects in Notion just got a big upgrade. With new advanced database filters, you have even more control and customizability over your database views - make them as specific as you want for a more organized and efficient workflow.
Relation and rollup properties
 Notion databases become even more powerful when you link them together. Link to a row from another database with a relation, or show a specific property from a related table with a rollup.

Chunk 952:
Notion for people ops
 Explain how Notion can keep teams on the same page and be able to set up Notion for large teams using teamspaces.
 Notion for HR & People operations
Questions?
 Email us
 team@makenotion.com

Timeline view

Chunk 958:
Timeline is a type of Notion database that’s way more than a Gantt chart. It gives you complete flexibility to scope projects, adjust their timelines, and customize your workflow.

• Sites
• Templates
 Databases are a powerful Notion feature that can unlock your toolmaking potential. Create databases, learn about layout types, and build databases for teams.
Intro to databases

Chunk 964:
Databases in Notion are collections of pages. Here, we'll introduce you to the general structure of a database, discuss the different menus and options, and deep dive into how to open and edit pages within a database. 🗃
Using database views
 Here, we'll introduce you to the different customization options and layouts that exist once you have a database set up in your workspace.
Timeline view
 Timeline is a type of Notion database that’s way more than a Gantt chart. It gives you complete flexibility to scope projects, adjust their timelines, and customize your workflow.
Table view

Chunk 965:
Tables are Notion's most traditional database view, but our tables are a lot more powerful than a grid with some rows and columns! Open each row as its own Notion page, or visualize in other database views.
Gallery view
 Galleries are Notion's most visual database view. Use them to showcase beautiful photos for mood boards, team directories, vacation photos and more.
List view
 Lists are Notion's most minimalist database view. All the power of a database, but without the visual clutter. Use them for meeting notes, journal entries, process documentation and more!
Board view

Chunk 966:
One of Notion's most powerful features, Boards are the best way to manage projects & tasks. Use them to group your databases by select, multiselect, and person properties.
Calendar view
 Calendars are a great way to visualize dates from any database in Notion. Use them for your company's social media planning, or add a calendar view to your product management databases.
Using database templates
 Instead of manually typing out the same structure and content for every new page, you can use database templates to automate your processes and save some time.
Using linked databases

Chunk 967:
Linked databases let you include synced copies of the same content across different pages. Use them to include a filtered view of team tasks in your meeting notes, or create a dashboard of tasks assigned to you from different databases.
Using advanced database filters
 Managing tasks and projects in Notion just got a big upgrade. With new advanced database filters, you have even more control and customizability over your database views - make them as specific as you want for a more organized and efficient workflow.
Relation and rollup properties
 Notion databases become even more powerful when you link them together. Link to a row from another database with a relation, or show a specific property from a related table with a rollup.

Chunk 968:
Notion for people ops
 Explain how Notion can keep teams on the same page and be able to set up Notion for large teams using teamspaces.
 Notion for HR & People operations

 Explain how Notion can keep teams on the same page and be able to set up Notion for large teams using teamspaces.
Notion for HR & People operations

Chunk 974:
With Notion, HR teams can create a single place where team members can go for benefits info, team directory, onboarding and more. In this video, we show you how to get this all set up, from scratch!
People ops: Navigating the sidebar
 Notion's sidebar has all the tools you need to organize your pages, add templates, access settings & more.
Setting up Notion for remote work
 You don't have to share an office with your team to get work done. We'll show you how to quickly set up a workspace for your team to collaborate remotely, as well as some tips and tricks along the way.
People ops: How to build a job board

Chunk 975:
Startups want to grow, but adding new roles or editing existing ones can be a bit of a pain. Notion solves this by giving teams a no code solution for hosting job listings and collecting applications.
People ops: Grow your startup with this applicant tracking system
 Organization is crucial in hiring. Use Notion to tag and filter candidates based on the teams they’d join, and where they’re at in the interview process.
People ops: Notion for admins of large teams
 This video will prep you on the features available only to Notion workspace admins — from deciding how your teammates, as well as people external to your team, interact with your workspace, to allowing third-party integrations.
People ops: Teamspaces for admins

Chunk 976:
Whether your team is 50 or 5,000, teamspaces can help ensure everyone has access to the right level of information that they need to do their job.
Notion for product and engineering teams
 Build three essential tools for product and engineering teams, and learn how Notion can support technical organizations to plan and execute more efficiently.
 Notion for engineers

 Build three essential tools for product and engineering teams, and learn how Notion can support technical organizations to plan and execute more efficiently.
Notion for engineers

Chunk 998:
If you’re an engineer and you’re new to Notion, you’ve found the right video. We’ll teach you how to create an engineering wiki and how you can set up your Notion to manage tasks and projects.
Notion for product managers
 Using Notion, product managers can conduct user research, prioritize feature requests, and connect the many dots that bring their products to life.
Product and Eng: Build a team notes and docs database
 It's easy for team members to help build a living record of meetings and decisions, so that anyone can find the information they need. We'll show you where to keep notes, how to build the databases that store them, and how to create dynamic links between your notes & projects.

Chunk 999:
Connecting your projects & tasks to meeting notes
 Using a relation property, you can connect your projects database to the tasks and meeting notes relevant to that project — giving your team full context for better execution.
Planning sprints for your engineering team
 High-output engineering teams use Notion to plan sprints so they can better focus on the task at hand.
Connecting tools to Notion
 How integrations can help you create a frictionless dialogue between the work you’re achieving outside Notion, and the work happening inside the app.
Notion for personal use
 Build 3 essential tools for daily life and explain how Notion can be used to support personal organization.
 Personal: Creating a page

 Using Notion, product managers can conduct user research, prioritize feature requests, and connect the many dots that bring their products to life.
Product and Eng: Build a team notes and docs database
 It's easy for team members to help build a living record of meetings and decisions, so that anyone can find the information they need. We'll show you where to keep notes, how to build the databases that store them, and how to create dynamic links between your notes & projects.

Chunk 1014:
Connecting your projects & tasks to meeting notes
 Using a relation property, you can connect your projects database to the tasks and meeting notes relevant to that project — giving your team full context for better execution.
Planning sprints for your engineering team
 High-output engineering teams use Notion to plan sprints so they can better focus on the task at hand.
Connecting tools to Notion
 How integrations can help you create a frictionless dialogue between the work you’re achieving outside Notion, and the work happening inside the app.

Personal: Writing and editing basics

Chunk 1021:
Every Notion page is highly customizable - learn how to format text and other content blocks to your liking.
Building a personal task page
 Since Notion is so flexible, you can manage your tasks however you want! But we'll show you two specific examples of task management pages that you can build yourself - one that's more lightweight, and one with more features and functionality.
Building a Journal
 Whether you're an avid journalist, or making journaling a new habit, you can store your entries in Notion! We'll show you two ways to build a journal in Notion, one for beginners, and one more advanced.
Building a reading list

Chunk 1022:
You stumble across interesting content every day - articles, blog posts, podcasts ... but it's hard to keep track of everything. With Notion's Web Clipper, you can stash it all in an organized database! We'll show you how to build this list from scratch.
Setting up Notion for school
 We'll show you how to upgrade your workspace for free, how to set up your workspace for keeping track of notes, thesis planning, job hunting and more, as well as how to collaborate with other students.
Workspace refresh
 Without proper maintenance, Notion workspaces can get messy over time. This course is designed to help you put structure and order back into your workspace.
 Preparing for a refresh
 Workspace Refresh course resource

Preparing for a refresh

Chunk 1044:
Learn what's involved with a workspace refresh, including the scope, timeline, and team communications.
Understanding the current state of the workspace
 Learn how teamspaces and the workspace owner role can bring structure to your workspace.
Establishing documentation and archival strategies
 Learn about Notion's Wiki feature and some best practices for archiving outdated content.
Finding and moving content
 Learn how to find high-traffic pages with analytics, then move them within the workspace using content search.
Building a company homepage
 Build a homepage for your company and learn to differentiate between company-wide and team-specific content.
Auditing the sidebar

Chunk 1045:
Learn what content belongs on the sidebar, and begin filing top-level pages into their relevant teamspaces.

• Sites
• Templates
Learn what's involved with a workspace refresh, including the scope, timeline, and team communications.

Chunk 1048:
- Auditing a workspace in Notion involves understanding how a company organizes knowledge on the platform and taking note of existing teamspaces and their content.- Teampspaces in Notion are used to separate different types of content or workflows within a workspace and their implementation should be planned.- It's important to ensure workspace members have the correct level of administrative access, with workspace owner being the highest level of administrator privilege.- Settings can be adjusted to control who can create new teamspaces and who can edit top-level pages of teamspaces.- Communication with the company about changes being implemented is key.
 Assignment

 Without proper maintenance, Notion workspaces can get messy over time. This course is designed to help you put structure and order back into your workspace.
Preparing for a refresh

Chunk 1060:
Learn what's involved with a workspace refresh, including the scope, timeline, and team communications.
Understanding the current state of the workspace
 Learn how teamspaces and the workspace owner role can bring structure to your workspace.
Establishing documentation and archival strategies
 Learn about Notion's Wiki feature and some best practices for archiving outdated content.
Finding and moving content
 Learn how to find high-traffic pages with analytics, then move them within the workspace using content search.
Building a company homepage
 Build a homepage for your company and learn to differentiate between company-wide and team-specific content.
Auditing the sidebar

Chunk 1061:
Learn what content belongs on the sidebar, and begin filing top-level pages into their relevant teamspaces.
Notion for Enterprise Admins
 Everything you need to deploy and manage Notion across your organization as an Admin.

Learn what's involved with a workspace refresh, including the scope, timeline, and team communications.

Chunk 1064:
- Auditing a workspace in Notion involves understanding how a company organizes knowledge on the platform and taking note of existing teamspaces and their content.- Teampspaces in Notion are used to separate different types of content or workflows within a workspace and their implementation should be planned.- It's important to ensure workspace members have the correct level of administrative access, with workspace owner being the highest level of administrator privilege.- Settings can be adjusted to control who can create new teamspaces and who can edit top-level pages of teamspaces.- Communication with the company about changes being implemented is key.
 Assignment

Chunk 1065:
Notion's Customer Success team has put together a Notion template to accompany this course. Duplicate it into your own Notion workspace and use it to follow along with the steps of the course as you refresh your own workspace.
 Duplicate the template here

Welcome to the connected workspace where better, faster work happens. Let’s cover all the things you need to know to begin exploring Notion.
Start here

Chunk 1098:
Curious about what Notion is? We'll show you right here, and in the articles to come. Let's go! 📍
What is a block?
 Think of Notion as a bottomless bin of building blocks. Build whatever you want, however you want! Every page you create in Notion will be composed of many "blocks," in the same way a LEGO castle is composed of many LEGO bricks 🧱
Create a page
 Every page you create in Notion is a fresh canvas where you can add whatever content you want. Follow these steps to create your first one 📄
Create a subpage
 There are no folders in Notion. Instead, you can organize pages inside pages... inside pages. Here, we'll show you how to create a page within another page, which we call a subpage 📑
What is a database?

Chunk 1099:
Databases are a core feature in Notion that help you manage and organize your pages. Let's explain what they are and how they can help you level up your workspace 🗄
Create a database
 Now we'll create a database and use it to show off essential database actions and features. You'll get to play with database properties, views, filters, and sorts - let's get into it 📈
Start with a template
 To help you take on a variety of challenges with Notion, we've created lots of templates that you can adopt and customize as your own — including 5 "starter templates" already in your workspace! Here's how to use them 💾
Share your work

Chunk 1100:
Share any Notion page you create with select people, your whole team, or the entire web. It's up to you. Here's a quick overview of how to share 🗣
Collaborate with people
 Notion has several features designed to improve and increase the velocity of communication with your team — whether you're all editing the same page or working across time zones 🤝

 We like to describe Notion as a set of building blocks for creating things you love to use on your computer, such as:
• Documents

Chunk 1104:

• Knowledge bases
• The world's most beautiful notes... 😉
 Documents
 Databases

 Knowledge bases
 Project management systems
 The world's most beautiful notes... 😉
 Notion is different from other software in a few ways. And once you master these basics, you can pretty much build whatever you want.
 Most importantly, don't worry about not knowing everything you can do right away. We'll discover it together. Click below to dive right in!

What is a block?

• Templates
Think of Notion as a bottomless bin of building blocks. Build whatever you want, however you want! Every page you create in Notion will be composed of many "blocks," in the same way a LEGO castle is composed of many LEGO bricks 🧱

Chunk 1108:
• Everything in Notion is a "block"
• Blocks can be rearranged
Everything in Notion is a "block"
 When you create your first page in Notion and begin typing, you've started with a text block. But Notion pages can contain a lot more than plain text!
 Imagine every piece of content you add to a page — whether it's text, an image, or a table — as a single building block. Every page is a stack of blocks combined however you want.
 Here's just one example page with different block types pointed out:
 Tip: Hit the / key on your keyboard (or tap the + button above your keyboard if you're on mobile) to see all the different types of content you can add.
Blocks can transform

Chunk 1109:
Any block in Notion can be turned into any other type of block in order to use, view, or deepen that information in a new way.
 Try this out by clicking the ⋮⋮ symbol and choosing Turn into to convert your block to something else!
Blocks can be rearranged
 The ⋮⋮ button can be used to drag and drop existing blocks. This makes it simple to rearrange, reorder, and reshape your thoughts with one motion.
Was this resource helpful?
Create a page
 Every page you create in Notion is a fresh canvas where you can add whatever content you want. Follow these steps to create your first one 📄

Every page you create in Notion is a fresh canvas where you can add whatever content you want. Follow these steps to create your first one 📄
• Start writing
• Try a slash command
Create a page

Chunk 1113:
There are a few ways to add a new page in Notion.
• Click 📝 at the top of your left sidebar.
• If you’re on the desktop app, use the shortcut cmd/ctrl + N.
• If you’re on mobile, tap 📝 at the bottom of your screen.
 Click 📝 at the top of your left sidebar.
 If you’re on the desktop app, use the shortcut cmd/ctrl + N.
 If you’re on mobile, tap 📝 at the bottom of your screen.
Start writing
 Once your new page opens, you can give your page a title and start jotting down your thoughts.

Chunk 1114:
Need some inspiration or structure? On desktop or web, select any of the options at the bottom of the page to get started. You can import from an app or file, use a template, create a table, and more — select an option you like, and your page will be formatted accordingly!
 As you write, highlight any text on your page to bring up a menu of options. You can change the color or style of your text, add a comment or hyperlink, and more. Learn more about writing and editing basics here →
Try a slash command
 The / command will quickly become your best friend in Notion.

Chunk 1115:
• Typing / brings up a comprehensive menu of block types - all of your content options. Experiment with different block types - you'll find your own personal favorite combinations!
• Add any type of block by typing / and scrolling to the one you want or typing its name. For instance, /h1 creates a large heading, and /todo creates a checkbox.
 Typing / brings up a comprehensive menu of block types - all of your content options. Experiment with different block types - you'll find your own personal favorite combinations!
 Add any type of block by typing / and scrolling to the one you want or typing its name. For instance, /h1 creates a large heading, and /todo creates a checkbox.

Chunk 1116:
There are no folders in Notion. Instead, you can organize pages inside pages... inside pages. Here, we'll show you how to create a page within another page, which we call a subpage 📑

There are no folders in Notion. Instead, you can organize pages inside pages... inside pages. Here, we'll show you how to create a page within another page, which we call a subpage 📑
• Create a subpage

Chunk 1119:
• Rearrange your page structure
Create a subpage
 A subpage is a page inside a page. You can create any number of subpages for a page.
 There are multiple ways to create a subpage:
• Open a page (this will be the subpage’s parent page) and use the slash command /page.
• Find your desired parent page in your sidebar and select + next to it. This will create a subpage in that page. When you return to the parent page, you’ll see the subpage there.
 Open a page (this will be the subpage’s parent page) and use the slash command /page.

Chunk 1120:
Find your desired parent page in your sidebar and select + next to it. This will create a subpage in that page. When you return to the parent page, you’ll see the subpage there.
 Once your new page opens, you can give your page a title and start jotting down your thoughts.
 Need some inspiration or structure? On desktop or web, select any of the options at the bottom of the page to get started. You can import from an app or file, use a template, create a table, and more — select an option you like, and your page will be formatted accordingly!
Navigate with your sidebar and breadcrumbs
 When you open the toggle for the parent page in your sidebar, you’ll see its subpages there.

Chunk 1121:
Additionally, at the top of your page, you’ll see breadcrumbs that show you what page you’re in, and where that page lives.
Rearrange your page structure
 The pages in your workspace can be easily rearranged.
• To take a subpage out of its parent page, click on it in the sidebar and drag it out of the parent page's toggle.
• To make a page a subpage, click on it in the sidebar and drag it into another page.
 To take a subpage out of its parent page, click on it in the sidebar and drag it out of the parent page's toggle.
 To make a page a subpage, click on it in the sidebar and drag it into another page.

What is a database?

Chunk 1122:
Databases are a core feature in Notion that help you manage and organize your pages. Let's explain what they are and how they can help you level up your workspace 🗄

Databases are a core feature in Notion that help you manage and organize your pages. Let's explain what they are and how they can help you level up your workspace 🗄
• Databases are pages themselves

Chunk 1125:
• Database views display the same content in different ways
Databases are collections of pages
 Think of Notion databases as filing cabinets or notebooks. Each database serves as a container, letting you easily organize multiple Notion pages in a single structure. In the screenshot below, every row of the table is a page within the database "Docs."
 This gives you a birds' eye view of an entire collection of pages at once. When you need to dive deeper, each page in a database can be opened, revealing its detailed contents.
Databases are pages themselves

Chunk 1126:
But wait - each database is also a page itself! This is powerful, because it allows you to move and nest databases alongside other content, just like any other page.
Databases have properties
 To help you organize all of the pages within a database, properties can be added to contextualize, label, and augment each individual item.
 You can then search, filter, and sort by these property values.
Database views display the same content in different ways
 Databases in Notion are not static. The set of pages within each database can be displayed in many different forms, or what we call views.

Chunk 1127:
In addition to table view, the contents of a database can be visualized as a list, board, calendar, gallery, or timeline - whatever makes the information the most useful.
Was this resource helpful?
Create a database
 Now we'll create a database and use it to show off essential database actions and features. You'll get to play with database properties, views, filters, and sorts - let's get into it 📈

Now we'll create a database and use it to show off essential database actions and features. You'll get to play with database properties, views, filters, and sorts - let's get into it 📈
• Add data to your table

Chunk 1130:
• Create new database views
• Filter and sort your data
Create a new table
 Add a new page and under Get started with and select Table.
 The first column is where you enter the name of your database pages. Each column in a Notion table corresponds to a property that gives your item context.
 Click a property heading, then Edit property and Type to see all of your property choices.
Add data to your table
 For this example, we'll create a task database.
 Add some tasks you're working on in the Name column.
 Now add some values to the Tags column using the multi-select property. The options could be something like P1, P2, and P3 to indicate the priority of a task.

Chunk 1131:
Add a new property using the + button to the right of the Tags heading.
 Change its name to Due Date. Click the property heading, then Edit property and Type and select Date. Now when you click on a cell under Due Date, you'll see the date picker.
Open a row as a page
 Every item in a Notion database is also a whole page of its own! You can add any content you want inside, including other databases.
 To open a row as a page, hover over a cell in the Name column and click OPEN.
 You can add or edit any properties.
• You can also add additional content into the body of the page.
 You can also add additional content into the body of the page.
Create new database views

Chunk 1132:
You can create different views of the same data. Put it into a board, a calendar, a list, a gallery, or a timeline — depending on your needs. Let's try one.
 Click + at the top of your table. Depending on your screen size, you may have to open the dropdown next to your current view and select Add view.
 Give your new view a name and choose Board from the right-side menu.
 This displays rows from your table into cards on a board, grouped by tag. Clicking on a card still opens it as a page. It's all the same content, just visualized in a different way!
 Learn more about views here →
 Tip: Different views are good for different things, and you can have as many as you need!
• Gallery view is great if you're storing images in your database.

Chunk 1133:
• Lists are helpful for minimalist storage of documentation.
• Calendar view displays your pages by an assigned date property.
• Timelines are useful for visualizing project dates and length.
 Gallery view is great if you're storing images in your database.
 Lists are helpful for minimalist storage of documentation.
 Calendar view displays your pages by an assigned date property.
 Timelines are useful for visualizing project dates and length.
Filter and sort your data
 Filter by property to focus on specific parts of your database.
 Click the filter icon at the top of your table, then select one of the default options or + Add advanced filter.

Chunk 1134:
Then select the criteria that needs to be met. The middle dropdown will give you different options depending on the property.
 In this case, let's choose Tags as the property, and say it must contain P1.
 Add sorts to reorder your database depending on property values. Sorts are helpful for quickly ordering your data by priority, date, tags, etc.
• Click ⇅ at the top of your table, then select the property you'd like to sort by.For example, choose Due Date and then Ascending. This reorders tasks from closest to furthest due date.
• For example, choose Due Date and then Ascending. This reorders tasks from closest to furthest due date.
 Click ⇅ at the top of your table, then select the property you'd like to sort by.

Chunk 1135:
• For example, choose Due Date and then Ascending. This reorders tasks from closest to furthest due date.
 For example, choose Due Date and then Ascending. This reorders tasks from closest to furthest due date.
 You'll see your database change in real time based on your filter and sort criteria. You can add as many filters and sorts as you want, and each view has its own filter and sorts.

To help you take on a variety of challenges with Notion, we've created lots of templates that you can adopt and customize as your own — including 5 "starter templates" already in your workspace! Here's how to use them 💾

Chunk 1139:
• Find & use in-app templates
• Duplicate community-made templates
Starter templates
 When you first sign up for Notion, you'll see a collection of 5 templates in your sidebar. These have been selected for you based on what you told us during onboarding. You can choose to add them to your workspace so you can edit them however you want, or remove them.
 To delete a template:
 Click the
•
•
• to the right of the page name.
 Then click Delete.
Find & use in-app templates
 You can access our full collection of in-app templates at any time. Look for Templates in your sidebar.
 Click Get template to actually add one to your workspace.
 Instructions are included inside each template in two ways:

Chunk 1140:
• For databases, they are at the top and can be hidden by hovering over the top of the page and clicking Hide description.
• For pages, instructions are scattered throughout in callout boxes that you can delete just like you'd delete any other content block.
 For databases, they are at the top and can be hidden by hovering over the top of the page and clicking Hide description.
 For pages, instructions are scattered throughout in callout boxes that you can delete just like you'd delete any other content block.
Duplicate community-made templates
 In addition to in-app templates, you can duplicate a public page into your own workspace as template. Learn more about public pages here →

Chunk 1141:
The Notion Template Gallery includes thousands of templates built for many purposes by Notion users around the world, which you can use as a starting point (or inspiration ✨)! Once you've duplicated a public template page into your own workspace, tweak it to match your workflow perfectly.
 Browse our Template Gallery: notion.so/templates →
FAQs
 Can I make my page a template to use elsewhere in my workspace?
 There isn't a way to customize the template picker, unfortunately. The best way to do this is:
• Keep an empty version of your template page in your left-hand sidebar.
• Click the
•
•
• next to that page's name in your sidebar, and then Duplicate whenever you need a new copy.

Chunk 1142:
Keep an empty version of your template page in your left-hand sidebar.
 Click the
•
•
• next to that page's name in your sidebar, and then Duplicate whenever you need a new copy.
 Depending on your use case, you might find these options useful!
• You can quickly duplicate chunks of content with a template button. Great for journaling! More on that here →
• In databases, you can create new database entries with the properties & page contents already populated by using database templates. More on that here →
 You can quickly duplicate chunks of content with a template button. Great for journaling! More on that here →

Chunk 1143:
In databases, you can create new database entries with the properties & page contents already populated by using database templates. More on that here →
 Do you have templates made by the Notion community anywhere?
 Yes! Indeed we do. Go to our Template Gallery at notion.so/templates to see creations across categories like work, media, personal productivity and more made by our community.
 Can I request a template for something?
 Yes! We'd love your ideas. Please tweet them to us at @Notion HQ (with the hashtag #template) or send them to our team at team@makenotion.com.

Share any Notion page you create with select people, your whole team, or the entire web. It's up to you. Here's a quick overview of how to share 🗣
• Share with your team
• Share with the web

Chunk 1147:
Share with one person
 You can invite people inside or outside your workspace to share a Notion page with you.
 Start with your page in Private in your sidebar.
 On the page, go to Share at the top right.
 Enter the person's name or email address in the space provided, choose a level of access, and click Invite.
• If the person is outside your workspace, they'll join the page as a guest.
• If the person is already a member of your workspace, you'll see their profile photo pop up in the invite menu, and the page will show up under Shared in your sidebar, as seen above.
 If the person is outside your workspace, they'll join the page as a guest.

Chunk 1148:
If the person is already a member of your workspace, you'll see their profile photo pop up in the invite menu, and the page will show up under Shared in your sidebar, as seen above.
Share with your team
 If you have multiple people working with you in Notion, you can quickly share any page with all of them. There are several ways to do this:
• Share with everyone in your workspace. Click Share at the top right of the page, and grant access to Everyone at [workspace name]. You can also assign everyone in your workspace a particular access level from the dropdown. For example, everyone Can view instead of being able to edit.

Chunk 1149:
• Create a page in any default teamspace in your sidebar. Everyone in your workspace is a member of default teamspaces and will automatically have access to pages in them. Learn more about teamspaces →
• Drag a private page to a default teamspace in your sidebar. This automatically shares it with everyone.
 Share with everyone in your workspace. Click Share at the top right of the page, and grant access to Everyone at [workspace name]. You can also assign everyone in your workspace a particular access level from the dropdown. For example, everyone Can view instead of being able to edit.

Chunk 1150:
Create a page in any default teamspace in your sidebar. Everyone in your workspace is a member of default teamspaces and will automatically have access to pages in them. Learn more about teamspaces →
 Drag a private page to a default teamspace in your sidebar. This automatically shares it with everyone.
• Share a page's URL. Every page in Notion has its own unique URL you can use to share it on Slack or elsewhere. Go to Share at the top right and click Copy link. Only people who have access to the page can see it.
 Share a page's URL. Every page in Notion has its own unique URL you can use to share it on Slack or elsewhere. Go to Share at the top right and click Copy link. Only people who have access to the page can see it.

Chunk 1151:
Share with the web
 You can easily turn your Notion page into a beautiful website with Notion Sites. Learn more about how to share your page with the web here →

Notion has several features designed to improve and increase the velocity of communication with your team — whether you're all editing the same page or working across time zones 🤝
• Work together in real-time
• Start a conversation

Chunk 1154:
• Leave a comment
• Never miss a thing
Work together in real-time
 You can edit the same page at the same time with an unlimited number of people.
• Their profile photos will show you where they're looking or working on the page.
• Edits and comments made by everyone will appear to you instantly.
• Click 🕘 at the top of the page to see who made what changes and when.Content added is highlighted in blue.Gray strikethrough shows what's been removed.You can also see where people have left comments.
• Content added is highlighted in blue.
• Gray strikethrough shows what's been removed.
• You can also see where people have left comments.
 Their profile photos will show you where they're looking or working on the page.

Chunk 1155:
Edits and comments made by everyone will appear to you instantly.
 Click 🕘 at the top of the page to see who made what changes and when.
• Content added is highlighted in blue.
• Gray strikethrough shows what's been removed.
• You can also see where people have left comments.
 Content added is highlighted in blue.
 Gray strikethrough shows what's been removed.
 You can also see where people have left comments.
Start a conversation
 There are several ways to communicate with your teammates inside Notion — hopefully helping you cut down on meetings and status checks.
Mention a teammate
 Want to get someone's attention on a page?
 Mention them by typing @ followed by their name anywhere on a page.

Chunk 1156:
You'll see a menu pop up that will search for the person in real time. Press enter.
• They'll be notified of your mention with a link directly to it in their Inbox (or with a push notification if they are on the desktop or mobile app).
 They'll be notified of your mention with a link directly to it in their Inbox (or with a push notification if they are on the desktop or mobile app).
Leave a comment
 Comments let you attach your thoughts, questions, or opinions to specific content on a page.
• To leave a comment on a page, click the Add comment right above its title.
• To leave a comment on text, highlight it, and click Comment in the menu that pops up.

Chunk 1157:
• To leave a comment on an image, embed, or other type of block, you can click the
•
•
• that appears at the top right or the ⋮⋮ icon that appears to the left on hover. Choose Comment from the menu that pops up. (You can also right click to bring it up!)
• You can @-mention your colleagues in comments to get their attention.
 To leave a comment on a page, click the Add comment right above its title.
 To leave a comment on text, highlight it, and click Comment in the menu that pops up.
 To leave a comment on an image, embed, or other type of block, you can click the
•
•
• that appears at the top right or the ⋮⋮ icon that appears to the left on hover. Choose Comment from the menu that pops up. (You can also right click to bring it up!)

Chunk 1158:
You can @-mention your colleagues in comments to get their attention.
Never miss a thing
 Notion is built for asynchronous communication. You'll be notified if someone needs you or if a page you care about has been changed.
 Click on Inbox at the top of your left sidebar. This is where we collect all notifications concerning you.
• All updates will appear with a grey badge. If you've been mentioned, you'll see a red badge with the number of mentions waiting for you next to Inbox.
 All updates will appear with a grey badge. If you've been mentioned, you'll see a red badge with the number of mentions waiting for you next to Inbox.
 Click on any of these updates to go directly to the comment, mention, or edit in question.

Chunk 1159:
Was this resource helpful?
Intro to workspaces
 Everything you do in Notion takes place in a workspace. It's your virtual home to organize information and create exactly the way you want — as just one person, together as a team, or across a whole company. Expand, edit, and mold it to fit your needs 🏠

Your Notion workspace is the home for all your content. You can work in your workspace alone or share your workspace with collaborators — it's up to you! Here, we'll teach you how to create, join, and use workspaces.

Chunk 1162:
Intro to workspaces
 Everything you do in Notion takes place in a workspace. It's your virtual home to organize information and create exactly the way you want — as just one person, together as a team, or across a whole company. Expand, edit, and mold it to fit your needs 🏠
Navigate with the sidebar
 Notion's left-hand sidebar makes it easy to structure all the content in your workspace. Here's everything you need to know on how to organize, rearrange, and find your pages within the sidebar 🧭
Create & manage workspaces

Chunk 1163:
When you're brand new to Notion, it's best to keep it simple and start with just one workspace. But as you start using Notion for more things, and with more groups of people, you can keep different kinds of content separate by using multiple workspaces 🏘
Create & navigate teamspaces
 Teamspaces help keep your content organized into specific areas. Keep your sidebar tidy by joining just the ones you need to access! Here's how 📚
Search in your workspace
 Notion is designed for you to add as many layers of information as you and your team need to solve any problem. Search ensures that Notion is an easily navigable archive of information 🔍
Home & My tasks

Chunk 1164:
Home gives you a view of all of the docs, tasks, and events that need your attention 🏡
Workspaces on mobile
 We've built Notion on mobile to replicate as much desktop functionality as possible. That said, there are a number of interactions that work differently by default. This is a quick tour of how Notion workspaces look and operate on your phone or tablet 📱

Chunk 1168:
Everything you do in Notion takes place in a workspace. It's your virtual home to organize information and create exactly the way you want — as just one person, together as a team, or across a whole company. Expand, edit, and mold it to fit your needs 🏠
• Sidebar
• Editor
• Control panel
• Sidebar sections
• Settings, templates, and trash
• Hover options
• Editor tools
• Collaborators
• Share menu
• Updates menu
•
•
•
• Help and support
• Team vs. personal workspaces
Workspace basics
 Your Notion app interface is split into two sections: the sidebar and the editor.
Sidebar
• Notion's expandable sidebar is your navigation system.

Chunk 1169:
• All the pages and databases you create will appear here.
• The sidebar contains several sections, which you can reorder and customize.
• You can nest pages inside each other for infinite levels of organization.
• It's also home to your settings, trash, and other tools.
 Notion's expandable sidebar is your navigation system.
 All the pages and databases you create will appear here.
 The sidebar contains several sections, which you can reorder and customize.
 You can nest pages inside each other for infinite levels of organization.
 It's also home to your settings, trash, and other tools.
 Learn more about your sidebar in this article →
Editor
• This is where all the content you create lives.

Chunk 1170:
• Control menus are at the top (we'll go through those in more detail), but otherwise, Notion's editor is a blank canvas for you to write, plan, brainstorm, and more.
• You'll notice that as soon as you start typing in this space, those top menus fade into the background, leaving you with your thoughts in a spacious zone of focus.
 This is where all the content you create lives.
 Control menus are at the top (we'll go through those in more detail), but otherwise, Notion's editor is a blank canvas for you to write, plan, brainstorm, and more.
 You'll notice that as soon as you start typing in this space, those top menus fade into the background, leaving you with your thoughts in a spacious zone of focus.
Sidebar tools
Control panel

Chunk 1171:
The control panel at the top of your sidebar contains several key features:
• Workspace switcher: Click on your current workspace's name to switch between the workspaces you belong to, create a new one, join another one, or log out. You can also access your settings from inside the workspace switcher. Learn more about switching workspaces here →
• Search: Click to open Notion's search window, where you can either type in what you're looking for or quickly jump to a recently visited page. Learn more about Search here →
• Home: Click to see the pages and tasks that need your attention. Learn more about Home here →

Chunk 1172:
• Inbox: Click to see all your notifications in one place. This menu combines revisions that were made on pages you follow, mentions of you across your workspace, and new work assignments. A red notification badge will appear here when you have unread notifications. Learn more about inbox here →
 Workspace switcher: Click on your current workspace's name to switch between the workspaces you belong to, create a new one, join another one, or log out. You can also access your settings from inside the workspace switcher. Learn more about switching workspaces here →
 Search: Click to open Notion's search window, where you can either type in what you're looking for or quickly jump to a recently visited page. Learn more about Search here →

Chunk 1173:
Home: Click to see the pages and tasks that need your attention. Learn more about Home here →
 Inbox: Click to see all your notifications in one place. This menu combines revisions that were made on pages you follow, mentions of you across your workspace, and new work assignments. A red notification badge will appear here when you have unread notifications. Learn more about inbox here →
Sidebar sections
 Your sidebar contains various sections to keep your workspace’s content organized:
• Teamspace: This section is accessible for users on paid plans to manage the various teams or groups that may be working in Notion. Learn more about teamspaces here →

Chunk 1174:
• Shared: This section contains pages that you and select others in your workspace have access to.
• Private: This section is home to pages that only you have access to.
• Favorites: This section houses pages that you’ve favorited so you can reference them easily.
 Teamspace: This section is accessible for users on paid plans to manage the various teams or groups that may be working in Notion. Learn more about teamspaces here →
 Shared: This section contains pages that you and select others in your workspace have access to.
 Private: This section is home to pages that only you have access to.
 Favorites: This section houses pages that you’ve favorited so you can reference them easily.

Chunk 1175:
You can rearrange and customize your sidebar sections. Learn how in this article →
 Tip:
• Click on the name of a sidebar section — Teamspaces, Shared, or Private — to collapse it and keep your sidebar nice and clean.
• Click and drag your sidebar sections to rearrange them.
 Click on the name of a sidebar section — Teamspaces, Shared, or Private — to collapse it and keep your sidebar nice and clean.
 Click and drag your sidebar sections to rearrange them.
 Note: If you drag a page into Private in your sidebar, everyone but you will lose access.
Favorites
 Favorites is where you can easily access all of the pages most important to you. This section will appear in your sidebar once you favorite your first page.

Chunk 1176:
To add a page to your favorites, navigate to it, then click ⭐ at the top of it. You'll see it appear under Favorites in your sidebar.
 To remove a page from your favorites, open it and unclick ⭐ at the top. You can also hover over the page in your sidebar and click
•
•
• . You'll see the option to Remove from Favorites.
 Tip: Favorites are helpful for stashing pages relevant to your current projects. You can easily add or remove them as your workflow and priorities change.
Settings, templates, and trash
• Settings allow you to adjust Notion to your preference. Learn more about settings here →
• Templates opens our template picker, where you can create a new page using starter content to help you accomplish your goals.

Chunk 1177:
• Trash contains all the pages you delete. You can drag and drop them in here. You can also click on trash to search, view, and restore these pages.
 Settings allow you to adjust Notion to your preference. Learn more about settings here →
 Templates opens our template picker, where you can create a new page using starter content to help you accomplish your goals.
 Trash contains all the pages you delete. You can drag and drop them in here. You can also click on trash to search, view, and restore these pages.
Create a new page
 There are a few ways to add a new page in Notion.
• Click 📝 at the top of your left sidebar.
• If you’re on the desktop app, use the shortcut cmd/ctrl + N.
• If you’re on mobile, tap 📝 at the bottom of your screen.

Chunk 1178:
Click 📝 at the top of your left sidebar.
 If you’re on the desktop app, use the shortcut cmd/ctrl + N.
 If you’re on mobile, tap 📝 at the bottom of your screen.
Hover options
 When you hover over a page in your sidebar, you'll see both a + button to add a page nested inside it, and a
•
•
• icon, which opens a menu of actions you can apply to the page: Delete, Duplicate, Copy link, Rename, and Move to.
Editor tools
Breadcrumb navigation
• Always know where you are in respect to your page structure. See how the page you're currently looking at fits into other pages.
• You can click on any page in this breadcrumb to immediately jump to it. Sometimes this will be abridged with a ... — click to view all the pages in between.

Chunk 1179:
Always know where you are in respect to your page structure. See how the page you're currently looking at fits into other pages.
 You can click on any page in this breadcrumb to immediately jump to it. Sometimes this will be abridged with a ... — click to view all the pages in between.
Collaborators
• You can see the profile photos of everyone else who has access to the page you're on. If you hover over any of them, you can see the full list, their names, and email addresses.
• Greyed out avatars are people who are not currently viewing the page but have access to it.
• When you collaborate in real-time on the same content, you can see people's photos moving around, corresponding to the block they're reading or editing.

Chunk 1180:
You can see the profile photos of everyone else who has access to the page you're on. If you hover over any of them, you can see the full list, their names, and email addresses.
 Greyed out avatars are people who are not currently viewing the page but have access to it.
 When you collaborate in real-time on the same content, you can see people's photos moving around, corresponding to the block they're reading or editing.
Share menu
• Each row in this menu represents a different person or group of people you can share the page with. The dropdown menus on the right let you set their level of access. Learn more about permissions here →

Chunk 1181:
• Copy link copies the page's unique URL to your clipboard so you can share it with whoever you want. Still, only people with access to the page can see it.
• Invite lets you add people both inside or outside your workspace to a page using their email address. Learn more about sharing here →
 Each row in this menu represents a different person or group of people you can share the page with. The dropdown menus on the right let you set their level of access. Learn more about permissions here →
 Copy link copies the page's unique URL to your clipboard so you can share it with whoever you want. Still, only people with access to the page can see it.

Chunk 1182:
Invite lets you add people both inside or outside your workspace to a page using their email address. Learn more about sharing here →
Updates menu
• Click the 🕘 clock icon to get an overview of all the revisions and comments made on the current page.
• Under Page notification settings you can change when you'd like to be notified.
• You'll see all notifications aggregated across all the pages you follow in the Inbox menu in your sidebar.
 Click the 🕘 clock icon to get an overview of all the revisions and comments made on the current page.
 Under Page notification settings you can change when you'd like to be notified.
 You'll see all notifications aggregated across all the pages you follow in the Inbox menu in your sidebar.
•
•
• menu

Chunk 1183:
This menu contains many options, including:
• Lock page: Turn this on to prevent any edits from being made. This is good for preventing accidental edits on very important pages.
• Lock database: This option is only available for full page databases. When you turn this on, people can still enter data, but they can’t change views or properties.
• Customize page: Toggle the visibility of backlink and page comment sections.
• Move to: This opens up a menu where you can choose any other workspace or page to move the current page into.
• View edit history: View past versions of the page going back several days, depending on what plan you're on.
• Recover pages: Opens up Trash so you can restore or permanently remove sub-pages you've deleted.

Chunk 1184:
• Import or sync from: You can add documents and data from a number of other apps (Evernote, Trello, Google Docs, etc.) to the page.
• Export: Download the page as a file to your computer. Databases get saved as CSV files, while non-database pages get saved as Markdown files. You can also export your page or database as PDF or HTML.
 Lock page: Turn this on to prevent any edits from being made. This is good for preventing accidental edits on very important pages.
 Lock database: This option is only available for full page databases. When you turn this on, people can still enter data, but they can’t change views or properties.
 Customize page: Toggle the visibility of backlink and page comment sections.

Chunk 1185:
Move to: This opens up a menu where you can choose any other workspace or page to move the current page into.
 View edit history: View past versions of the page going back several days, depending on what plan you're on.
 Recover pages: Opens up Trash so you can restore or permanently remove sub-pages you've deleted.
 Import or sync from: You can add documents and data from a number of other apps (Evernote, Trello, Google Docs, etc.) to the page.
 Export: Download the page as a file to your computer. Databases get saved as CSV files, while non-database pages get saved as Markdown files. You can also export your page or database as PDF or HTML.
